Wireless connectivity of voting machines is a concern when it comes to the potential for hacking an election. If they survive a review process, new rules would represent a landmark development in voting technology oversight, eliminating one of cybersecurity experts‚Äô top concerns about voting machines by plugging holes that skilled hackers could exploit to tamper with the democratic process.

The new draft of the 2.0 version of the Voluntary Voting System Guidelines says that voting machines and ballot scanners ‚Äúmust not be capable of establishing wireless connections,‚Äù ‚Äúestablishing a connection to an external network‚Äù or ‚Äúconnecting to any device that is capable of establishing a connection to an external network.‚Äù These aren't  a set of mandatory federal rules. However, most states require voting equipment to pass VVSG-based testing before they buy it. More at the link in our bio. üì∑ Getty

Former Sen. Kay Hagan (D-N.C.) has died. She was 66.

Hagan was a former bank executive who rose from a budget writer in the North Carolina Legislature to a seat in the U.S. Senate. She served a single term in the Senate after defeating Republican Elizabeth Dole for the seat in 2008. She lost to Republican Thom Tillis in 2014.

Hagan died of encephalitis, or brain inflammation, caused by Powassan virus, a rare virus spread from ticks to humans, her former Senate spokeswoman Sadie Weiner said. More at the link in bio. üì∑ Getty

The Air Force has concluded scores of overnight stays at President Trump's seaside resort in Scotland did not violate any rules. But the stays did raise questions about the "public perception" of funneling taxpayer funds to a property owned by the commander in chief.

The review was overseen by the Air Mobility Command. It recommended that aircrew commanders receive additional training to help them decide where to house personnel on overseas missions that include stopovers at civilian airfields such as Glasgow Prestwick Airport, about 40 minutes from Trump's golf resort. The report did conclude there had been no wrongdoing. More at the link in bio. üì∑ Getty

Trump pledged to prevent atrocities. Now he may face one on his watch. U.S. lawmakers, rights activists and others feared that the worst is yet to come for the Kurds and other ethnic and religious minorities who had created a semi-safe haven in northeast Syria. The Turkish incursion already has displaced more than 100,000 people.

Videos posted by various media outlets showed Kurds pelting exiting U.S. military vehicles with rotten fruit and stones, accusing America of betraying them. Inside the Trump administration, officials are watching in a daze, unsure of what they can say even to each other. ‚ÄúThe Syria thing is a great example of where the president does something, and everyone has to sit around a room and figure out how to make it happen, and no one wants to say it‚Äôs stupid,‚Äù an administration official said. History was made today high above the Earth üåé. Floating out of the International Space Station to fix a broken part of the power network, NASA astronauts Christina Koch and Jessica Meir emerged one by one, marking the first time in a half-century of spacewalking that a woman floated out without a male crewmate üõ∞. NASA originally wanted to conduct an all-female spacewalk last spring, but did not have enough medium-size suits ready to go. Koch and Meir were supposed to install more new batteries in a spacewalk next week, but had to venture out three days earlier to deal with an equipment failure that occurred over the weekend. They need to replace an old battery charger for one of the three new batteries that was installed last week by Koch and Andrew Morgan.

This likely won‚Äôt be NASA‚Äôs only all-female spacewalk. In about three years, if all goes as planned, the American government will launch a cylinder-shaped module 250,000 miles into space and insert it into orbit around the moon üåë. It will be followed by other capsules that will join together to create the Lunar Gateway. The Lunar Gateway is the biggest single project on NASA‚Äôs agenda, and the centerpiece of President Trump‚Äôs promised plan to go to the moon. It would be the first permanent human presence outside of low Earth orbit, and it is designed to serve many purposes: to host science experiments, to resupply missions to the moon‚Äôs surface, and to serve as a stop-off point where astronauts can board long-term missions to deep space, including someday to Mars. Current plans call for astronauts to move in to the station‚Äôs first phase around 2024 and soon thereafter start traveling regularly to the moon's surface, marking a new era in the halting but dramatic story of human progress off our home planet. We explored why experts and the industry are divided over the Lunar Gateway earlier this year (link in bio). üì∑ NASA via AP

Confused about cannabis? You‚Äôre not alone. Let us help you break down the difference between cannabis, hemp and marijuana.

Marijuana and hemp are the same species of plant, known scientifically as cannabis sativa L. Both marijuana and hemp can be referred to as cannabis. Under U.S. law, cannabis that contains less than 0.3 percent THC is hemp, and cannabis that contains more than 0.3 percent THC is marijuana. But this distinction is a legal one, not a scientific one. Other jurisdictions have different definitions ‚Äî Switzerland, for example, defines hemp as cannabis that contains less than 1 percent THC. Want to know more about cannabis? We break down what you should know at the link in our bio. üé® @mjolanbloom/POLITICO

With marijuana illegal in any form at the federal level, states have been forging their own paths to medical and recreational use. As a result there's a patchwork of laws for adult-use and medical marijuana across the nation. Although federal law still designates marijuana as an illegal ¬†Schedule I drug, 48¬†states have laws on the books that allow or decriminalize the use of cannabis in some form.

Eleven states and Washington, D.C. have legalized ‚Äî¬†and 15 states have decriminalized ‚Äî¬†adult-use cannabis, which usually allows retail sales and home-grown marijuana on a mixed basis. A majority of states have enacted medical marijuana laws, which allow eligible patients to obtain or grow cannabis to treat a range of conditions. More about where each state stands on marijuana at the link in our bio.

Could facial recognition technology be coming to an airport near you? It‚Äôs already a daily reality in this Arizona border town. For months, agents have been scanning the faces of every person who crosses here by foot ‚Äì and it‚Äôs part of a pilot program testing whether it's possible to police America's borders and airports with tech that's better than humans at verifying identification.

But not everyone is convinced the tech is ready for the real world. There are concerns that it makes mistakes (especially with black and brown faces) and that it‚Äôs a privacy threat since the government could track people without their knowledge or develop portfolios of photos of citizens.

In response to privacy complaints, CBP promised to delete photos within 12 hours of confirming someone‚Äôs identity. But that would only apply to U.S. citizens. For non-citizens, the agency would hold onto their photos for up to 14 days before transferring them to a Homeland Security database. They would be stored there for 75 years.

Link in bio for more on the ongoing debate around installing facial recognition technology at our borders. üì∑ Kathleen Flynn for Politico Magazine

In her first 14 months as Transportation secretary, Elaine Chao met with officials from Kentucky vastly more often than those from any other state. In fact, 25% of Chao‚Äôs scheduled meetings with local officials of any state from Jan. 2017 to March 2018 were from Kentucky.

In case you didn‚Äôt know, Chao is married to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, a Republican who represents Kentucky. It turns out that at least five of Chao‚Äôs 18 meetings with local Kentuckians were requested in emails from McConnell staffers. McConnell‚Äôs team alerted Chao‚Äôs staffers which of the officials were ‚Äúfriends‚Äù or ‚Äúloyal supporters,‚Äù according to records obtained by POLITICO under the Freedom of Information Act.

The fact that Chao‚Äôs calendar shows that one out of every four meetings with local officials was with Kentuckians is significant because the department has long maintained that it, and she, have shown no favoritism to the state represented by her husband, even while local officials from other states have complained about having trouble getting to see her. Joe Biden first ran for president in the 1988 election cycle. So it‚Äôs no surprise that the Democratic front-runner turns 77 next month. And this time around his age is the subtext, and increasingly the text, too, of not only his bid but the Democratic Party‚Äôs primary as a whole.

Canada's election sprint has begun. Our northern neighbor has kicked off six weeks of nationwide campaigning before voters decide on Oct. 21 whether Liberal Prime Minister Justin Trudeau will get a second term. Trudeau's main challenger is Conservative Party Leader Andrew Scheer, but individual races for 338 House of Commons seats from across the country will determine which party will form the next government. Canada is a parliamentary democracy in the British tradition, meaning voters don‚Äôt directly select the prime minister. In order for Trudeau to maintain power, his Liberals must win the most ridings, or electoral districts, and the margin of victory will influence the form the next government takes ‚Äî whether it's a majority or a minority arrangement. Link in bio for a five-step primer on how Canadian federal elections work. üì∏ Getty Images

The campaign said that over 90% of the email addresses are new, a huge expansion of the candidate's email list. The oil industry is trying to crush the booming electric car movement. Groups backed by industry giants like Exxon Mobil and the Koch empire are waging a state-by-state, multimillion-dollar battle to crack down on utilities‚Äô plans to build charging stations across the country. The showdown is taking place as utilities, eager to increase the demand for power, push for approval to build charging networks in locations such as shopping centers and rest stops in more than half the nation. And oil groups are far from alone in critiquing the utility charging proposals. Consumer advocates and some independent charging firms argue that utilities, which operate as monopolies, are using electric vehicle infrastructure to pad their balance sheets because their captive customers will have to pay for the investments. Mitch McConnell endorsed a short-term spending bill to avoid a government shutdown‚Äîwhich would happen on Sept. 30 without a deal. North Carolina has an election tomorrow‚Äîa do-over election, actually. NC voters will go to the polls to choose a congressional representative after the race was marred by allegations of fraud last year. The election between Democrat Dan McCready and Republican Dan Bishop will take place in a Republican-leaning slice of the state. It exemplifies the key push-pull of politics in the Trump era: Cities and suburbs racing away from the GOP and toward Democrats ‚Äî and rural and exurban voters roaring back in the other direction, propelled by President Trump‚Äôs appeal. Trump will hold a rally for Bishop tonight in Fayetteville, seeking to boost GOP turnout. Link in bio for the full story. üì∏ AP Photo

We‚Äôre in a historic moment for marijuana and cannabis policy right now. 11 states and D.C. have legalized recreational use. 33 states have made marijuana at least partially legal. And public support is growing: Nearly ‚Öî of Americans are in favor of legalization, according to Gallup.

But cannabis is still illegal at the federal level, and lawmakers on both sides of the aisle are struggling over where to start. Right now there are two marijuana bills in front of Congress: the MORE Act and the SAFE Banking Act. But which one should lawmakers tackle first? And which has a better chance of actually passing Congress? Link in bio for all the details.

Kirsten Gillibrand's exit from the presidential race leaves five women still in the running. We emailed one of them, Sen. Amy Klobuchar, to find out what it's really like to be a woman vying for the top office in 2020.

On one of the first times she realized people would treat her differently because she's a woman: "In fourth grade I was sent home for being the first girl to wear pants at Beacon Heights Elementary in Plymouth, Minnesota. I was sent to the principal's office for wearing bell-bottoms ... I wish I could say I talked back, started a petition drive, or filed a lawsuit but as the good girl who had never been called into the principal's office, I cried, walked home, put on a skirt, and went back to school. But in the years since I've learned how to talk back, stand up for what's right, and start those petition drives. If you want to make change, you've got to do it yourself." Link in bio for more from what Klobuchar had to say in this week's Women Rule newsletter. üì∏ @smahaskey

Michigan State University will be fined a record $4.5 million over its handling of sexual abuse allegations against Larry Nassar. Nassar, the sports doctor who treated Olympic gymnasts, was sentenced to 40 to 175 years in prison after more than 150 women and girls said he had sexually abused them. Walmart says it will stop selling handgun ammunition and publicly request that customers refrain from openly carrying firearms in stores even though state laws may allow it. The announcement comes just days after a mass shooting claimed seven lives in Odessa, Texas, and follows two other back-to-back shootings last month, one of them at a Walmart store. It will also discontinue handgun sales in Alaska, marking its complete exit from handguns and allowing it to focus on hunting rifles and ammunition for those rifles only. Hurricane Dorian came to a catastrophic daylong halt over the northwest Bahamas. The storm flooded the islands of Abaco and Grand Bahama, trapping people in attics and drowning the Grand Bahama airport under 6 feet of water. At least five people died and 21 injured people were airlifted to the capital by the U.S. Coast Guard, Bahamas officials said. One radio station said it received more than 2,000 distress messages, including reports of a 5-month-old baby stranded on a roof and a woman with six grandchildren who cut a hole in a roof to escape rising floodwaters.  Hundreds of thousands of people in Florida, Georgia and South Carolina were ordered to evacuate before the storm rolls up the Eastern Seaboard, bringing the possibility of life-threatening storm-surge flooding even if the storm‚Äôs heart stays offshore, as forecast. It‚Äôs official. President Trump formally established a new military headquarters for space operations today. This is part of his efforts to ensure the Pentagon maintains an edge over potential adversaries like Russia and China. The U.S. Space Command will be responsible for defending military satellites and other space systems and will draw on troops from other branches of the military as well as Trump's proposed Space Force, which is still awaiting approval from Congress. Gen. John Raymond, the current head of the Air Force Space Command, has been tapped to run the new outfit. The new command will include 287 personnel at a location that has yet to be determined. The Pentagon is reportedly considering six locations at bases in Colorado, Alabama and California. Link in bio. üì∑ Getty Images

Did you know that climate change could lead to contaminated drinking water? Seriously. According to scientists heavier rains that come from a warming of the planet could cause water tables to seep into the ash left behind when coal is burned for the generation of power. This ash contains arsenic, selenium, lead, mercury, boron and other contaminants that are known to cause cancer, neurological damage or heart ailments. More than 100 storage sites for coal-burning power plants‚Äô toxic leftovers lie in areas that federal emergency managers have labeled a high risk for flooding, according to POLITICO‚Äôs examination of government and industry data. Meanwhile, the Trump administration is moving to weaken an Obama-era regulation meant to prevent a repeat of past coal ash disasters. More at the link in bio. üé® Tucker Doherty/POLITICO

What was already expected to be a difficult summit ‚Äî with Germany lurching toward recession and Britain facing the trauma of a no-deal Brexit ‚Äî has now become openly confrontational. Link in bio for more on Trump‚Äôs storm into the G7 summit. üì∏ AP Photo

A transformation is underway in presidential politics. After decades of taking home less pay and fighting to have a say in major decisions, women are now a dominant force at the highest levels of Democratic presidential campaigns ‚Äî and they‚Äôre getting paid equitably for their work, a POLITICO analysis shows. For years it was common for female staffers to earn $10,000 or $20,000 less than men for doing the same work, said Anne Caprara, who ran Hillary Clinton‚Äôs 2016 super PAC, Priorities USA. That‚Äôs no longer the norm. Link in bio for more.

President Trump responded with fury this evening after taking a pair of blows this morning when China announced a fresh round of tariffs and Fed Chairman Jay Powell did not explicitly pledge aggressive interest rate cuts as the president demanded. The president struck back at China by saying he would hike already existing tariffs on $250 billion in Chinese imports from 25 percent to 30 percent starting Oct. 1. In addition, tariffs on $300 billion worth of other goods would increase from 10 percent to 15 percent as originally planned starting on Sept. 1. Trump said in announcing the tariff hikes that he'd done so because "in the spirit of achieving Fair Trade, we must Balance this very unfair Trading Relationship" with China, which he said had become a "great burden" to taxpayers. Investors had been in a relatively forgiving mood after China‚Äòs tariffs and the Fed speech, but Trump‚Äôs tweets triggered a sharp sell-off in the stock market, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down more than 600 points and the S&P 500 tumbling about 2.6 percent by the end of trading. The president‚Äôs own tariff escalation came an hour after regular trading closed for the week. Link in bio.

The Amazon rainforest is on fire. And President Trump is ready to help. Nearly 40,000 fires have incinerated Brazil, the latest outbreak in an overactive fire season that has charred 1,330 square miles of the rainforest this year. ‚ÄúWe stand by ready to assist!" President Trump tweeted today after a phone call with Brazil President Jair Bolsonaro. The tweet comes after reports of French President Emmanuel Macron's plans to oppose a long-anticipated trade deal involving Brazil as a result of Bolsonaro's role in deforestation in his country. This could make things awkward for Trump and Macron at this weekend‚Äôs G7 summit. More at the link in bio. üì∑ AP

Today marks the 30th anniversary of the Baltic Way, when more than 1 million Baltic residents across Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania formed a 420-mile human chain to demonstrate for freedom from the Soviet Union. On Friday Lithuanian people joined hands to commemorate the anniversary in Cathedral Square in Vilnius, Lithuania. Thousands of miles away, pro-democracy demonstrators in Hong Kong borrowed the idea (swipe üëà). Inspired to create the "Hong Kong Way," based on the events 30 years ago, demonstrators linked arms to form 25 miles of human chains. üì∏ AP Photo

Do you remember Bob Cousy? President Trump called the 91-year old Boston Celtics star ‚Äúone of the all-time greats in the history of sports." Cousy played for the Celtics from 1950 to 1963, winning six league championships and the 1957 MVP title. The Bob Cousy Award, given to the country's best point guard in men's college basketball, is named for him. He is a member of the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame and played a pivotal role in founding the NBA Player's Association. And after hanging up his No. 14 jersey, the 13-time NBA All-Star went on to coach basketball at Boston College. Today, Cousy added Presidential Medal of Freedom honoree to his list of accomplishments after Trump presented him with the award in the Oval Office. Cousy is the second Medal of Freedom recipient this year. Trump presented the award to golfer Tiger Woods in May.
üì∑ AP

Trump thinks tariffs will add U.S. manufacturing jobs. Economic reality says they won‚Äôt. It's true that firms are indeed moving out of China, but they aren't flocking to the United States, undermining the central promise of Trump‚Äôs trade war. Cheaper labor markets in Southeast Asia are the ones benefiting the most amid the trade war that has ratcheted up duties on Chinese goods. We visited a manufacturing plant in South Carolina, the Bicycle Corporation of America, where workers were assembling a variety of bikes using parts produced from partners in China. Those parts are subject to increases in tariffs proposed by the Trump administration. Link in bio for more on what we learned visiting the plant. üì∏ @smahaskey

Planned Parenthood will give up millions of dollars in federal grants rather than comply with a new Trump administration rule that bars federally funded clinics from referring patients to abortion providers. The organization threatened to do this for months, but they made their move official ahead of a midnight deadline. Planned Parenthood's exit from the Title X program will leave low-income women in many parts of the country without federally-funded access to birth control and other reproductive health services. "When you have an unethical rule that is asking us to limit what our providers can tell our patients, then it becomes really important for us to not agree to be in the program," acting President Alexis McGill Johnson said. Something happened on Wall Street today that has investors freaked out. There was a red flag in the bond market, and it has economists warning of a recession. First, a little markets 101: Ahead of each of the last 10 recessions, investors demanded more interest on two-year Treasury debt compared to 10-year debt. It‚Äôs usually a sign of weaker growth expected in the years ahead. And that's what happened today. (Wall Street calls this a ‚Äúyield curve inversion.‚Äù) This ‚Äúinversion‚Äù might sound like wonky finance-speak. But it‚Äôs a closely watched measure that sends an important signal about the health of the economy. Trump administration officials, meanwhile, strongly reject the idea that we‚Äôre headed for recession ‚Äî which would definitely hurt the president‚Äôs reelection prospects. Link in bio for the full story. üì∑AP

Trump's escalating trade war with China is bad news for Wall Street. The latest cause: The Trump administration made the rare step of labeling China as a currency manipulator. The last time the Treasury designated any country as a currency manipulator was in the early 1990s, when China was named. The trade tensions had already driven stocks lower Monday before the Treasury‚Äôs designation. Both the Dow Jones Industrial Average and the broader S&P 500 fell around 3%, extending losses from last week. So what's this all mean? The Treasury's action "is more symbolic than anything at this point and aimed at Trump's hard core political base," said Joe Brusuelas, chief economist at RSM. "Moreover, it marks the start of a process that may end in the Trump administration attempting to devalue the dollar." Plus, some economists are fearing a disastrous replay of U.S. actions under the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act in the 1930s and tit-for-tat responses by other countries that many blame for prolonging the Great Depression. Link in bio for more. üì∏ AP Photo

#trade #trump #donaldtrump #economy #wallstreet #nyse

One of the nation's leading climate scientists is quitting the Agriculture Department in protest. The majority of House Democrats now support an impeachment inquiry. Supporters passed the halfway mark ‚Äî 118 out of 235 voting Dem members now support the effort ‚Äî on Thursday when Rep. Ted Deutch of Florida announced his support. ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Perhaps more significant than the number of Democrats backing an inquiry are the identities of the members themselves. The latest additions include Reps. Mike Levin of California, Jennifer Wexton of Virginia and Jason Crow of Colorado, three freshmen who flipped Republican-held districts in November. Rep. Katherine Clark of Massachusetts, a member of Speaker Nancy Pelosi's leadership team, added her name to the list last week.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Even though Pelosi has given no indication that even a significant majority of House Dems embracing impeachment would shift her view, supporters of an inquiry argue that crossing the halfway mark among the caucus is a symbolic boost that could shift the political dynamic. Link in bio for more.

Analysis: Tuesday‚Äôs Democratic debate wasn‚Äôt exactly an invigorating night. It was too long (about 2 hours, 45 minutes) and too disorienting (candidates clamoring to be heard; moderators cutting in with impatient ‚Äúthank yous‚Äù to shut down long answers) for that. But in its own way it was illuminating. The debate showed us a party arguing seriously about the tension between boldness and realism on topics like health care, immigration, taking on wealthy interests, and energizing average voters. And at least half a dozen of the first eight opening statements included explicit or implied rebukes of the leftward tilt of the party. Jay Inslee is running as the climate change candidate. But he‚Äôs also the 2020 Dem who may actually know how to fix health care ‚Äì a key issue in the presidential race.

His administration pushed forward a new plan for controlling drug costs, expanded Medicaid coverage to transgender patients and added programs for school children aimed at preventing chronic diseases later in life.

Immigration hard-liner Ken Cuccinelli has somehow made his way into an extraordinary position of power. A few weeks ago, the president named him the acting head of the relatively obscure U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services. He's supposed to run an agency responsible for processing immigration paperwork and vetting asylum applicants, not border enforcement. But instead, Cuccinelli quickly became one of Trump's top officials for his aggressive immigration agenda, despite having little relevant policy experience. They've met multiple times to talk about the administration's plan to stop the flow of migrants across the U.S. border. Their relationship is so new that even Cuccinelli‚Äôs boss, acting Homeland Security Secretary Kevin McAleenan, wasn't aware of these meetings with Trump.

Cuccinelli's quick rise into Trump-led inner circle also shows how the White House is eager to put the most critical immigration decisions into the hands of a small group of like-minded people, without the vetting and oversight that would come from a more traditional bureaucratic structure. Link in bio for the full story. üì∑AP

Momentum for an impeachment inquiry seems to be growing since Robert Mueller‚Äôs testimony before Congress last week. More than a dozen Democrats have newly signaled their support since Mueller‚Äôs testimony, including four House rank-and-file members backing the movement as recently as Sunday.

This indicates an increasing acceptance in the top rungs of Washington for Democrats to keep their political fire trained on President Donald Trump and may pressure House Speaker Nancy Pelosi to take action. More at the link in bio.

‚ÄúCan you contribute even one dollar?‚Äù billionaire Tom Steyer has been asking voters in millions of dollars worth of advertisements.

Buried in Trump‚Äôs tax law that he signed in late 2017 was a small section that had very little to do with tax reform. It was a provision that reversed a federal policy and opened about 1.6 million acres of protected land in Alaska to oil and gas leasing.

For decades, the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge (swipe üëà for a map) has been the subject of a tug of war between pro-drilling forces and conservation advocates determined to protect an ecosystem crucial to polar bears, migratory caribou and native communities that rely on the wildlife for subsistence hunting. Trump‚Äôs Tax Cuts and Jobs Act handed the advantage decisively to the drillers for the first time since the refuge was established in 1980. Link in bio to read our full investigation.

Meet the United Kingdom's new prime minister: Boris Johnson. The former mayor of London and leader of the Brexit campaign beat his rival, Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt, by 66% of the votes. But it's also important to know that only 1% of the country voted in the election. That's because only members of the Conservative Party were eligible to vote. Due to Britain's parliamentary system, the prime minister is elected by the governing party. In Johnson's acceptance speech, he told the party there would be people around the country ‚Äúwho will question the wisdom of your decision.‚Äù But he said those in the room did not look or feel ‚Äúdaunted‚Äù by the challenge of Brexit. He pledged to get Brexit done by the upcoming October 31 deadline‚Äîsomething his predecessor Theresa May was not on track to accomplish. May spent the last three years trying to deliver Brexit, only to resign in May after British lawmakers turned down her deal three times. Link in bio for the full story. üì∏Getty Images

The Trump administration is considering a virtual shutdown of refugee admissions next year ‚Äî cutting the number to nearly zero ‚Äî according to three people familiar with the plan. Minneapolis did something bold to address its affordable housing crisis. The city council abolished single-family-home zoning and will allow duplexes and triplexes to be built anywhere in the city. But Minneapolis‚Äô new vision of itself would essentially rewrite that code‚Äîreshaping the urban streetscape around walking and mass transit and rebooting the American dream to be more racially and economically inclusive. Janne Flisrand and John EdwardsüëÜare leading that charge with their group, Neighbors for More Neighbors. Colonial Williamsburg reportedly draws about half the number of visitors it attracted in the 1980s, the last decade of the Cold War. Where once families yearned to see that history firsthand, they now blow past that turnoff on the way to the beach. Are Americans falling out of love with their landmarks? Happy Fourth of Julyüéâüá∫üá∏. On this day 243 years ago, delegates from the 13 original colonies and the Continental Congress officially declared independence from Great Britain. The declaration, mostly written by Thomas Jefferson, was the early United States' formal decision to free itself from the monarchy of King George III. "The flames kindled on the 4 of July 1776, have spread over too much of the globe to be extinguished by the feeble engines of despotism; on the contrary, they will consume these engines and all who work them," Jefferson later wrote to John Adams, as nations around the world followed suit in rejecting tyranny in favor of democracy.

As president Donald Trump readies his Independence Day remarks later today, here are some photos of past U.S. presidents commemorating America's birthday. üì∑:AP

We‚Äôre more likely to elect a woman in 2020, civil rights attorney Cyrus Mehri writes in @politicomag. Studies tell us there‚Äôs a huge difference between having just one versus multiple women competing for a job. For example, if only one diverse candidate ends up in an interview pool, companies will favor hiring a white man.

But, as authors of one study found, when multiple diverse candidates enter the field, the status quo actually changes, and company decisions do, too. The playing field starts to level out. In other words, it‚Äôs too much to ask one woman to break the glass ceiling. But collectively, the half dozen women running for the nation‚Äôs highest office can do it. "Judge has spoken with most all of you on the phone over the past few weeks and is appreciative of your warm support," Kayla Moore wrote in the note, a copy of which was obtained by POLITICO. "We will be making an official announcement regarding the [Senate] race in Montgomery this Thursday" afternoon. Moore lost to Democrat Doug Jones in a 2017 special election amid allegations of decades-old sexual misconduct by Moore with young girls. Jones is running for reelection next year and is considered one of the most vulnerable senators of the cycle. Link in bio for more. üì∏ Getty Images

Trump supporters lined up more than 40 hours early for the president‚Äôs Orlando rally, where he will officially launch his 2020 campaign. As the president kicks of his campaign tonight, there are two ways to view the political climate in Trump‚Äôs Washington:

THE PRO-TRUMP WORLD: As the president and his allies see it, a second term should be his for the taking. The economy is solid ‚Äî inflation is low and growth is chugging along, despite some warning signs. And even with withering pressure from investigations, Republicans are not abandoning the president.

THE ANTI-TRUMP WORLD: Trump‚Äôs foes are just as certain he‚Äôs got a losing record. Trade wars with Mexico and China are hurting farmers in the Midwest and pushing up prices for everyone else. Plus, impeachment looms on the horizon.  AND YET, here‚Äôs the thing about Trump: After he shocked the world in 2016, nobody dares predict which narrative will prevail in 2020.  Tap the link in our  bio for more in today's Playbook. üì∏ AP Photo

Hundreds and sometimes thousands at a time, Honduran migrants have joined caravans of Central Americans making their way north through Mexico to seek refuge in the United States. Violence‚Äîparticularly domestic and sexual violence‚Äîin Honduras has taken or forever changed many women‚Äôs and girls lives. And in a country where emergency contraception and abortion are banned, even for rape victims, survivors of sexual violence have few options if they become pregnant. This week 100 years ago, Congress approved the women's suffrage amendment and sent it to the states for ratification.

The House voted 304-89 and Senate 56-25 in favor of the then-pending 19th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, and Elizabeth Cady Stanton, Susan B. Anthony, Lucy Stone and other prominent suffragists joined their women‚Äôs rights groups together for the following state-by-state battles for ratification.

The text, which closely follows the wording of the 15th Amendment, reads: ‚ÄúThe right of citizens of the United States to vote shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on account of sex. Congress shall have power to enforce this article by appropriate legislation.‚Äù And this week, Republican and Democratic Sens. Susan Collins, Dianne Feinstein and others crossed the aisle to remember the 56 Senate yeas approving their voting rights in 1919, which has led to record numbers of women holding elected office in 2019.
‚Äî‚Äî

This Northern California town, decimated by wildfires, is trying to rebuild a health care system in a place that no longer exists for a future that‚Äôs impossible to predict. Paradise, California, is little more than a large charred debris removal site ‚Äî and it lost its hospital, several clinics, its nursing homes, its doctors in the fire last year. Without health care the town has no chance of coming back. Now, it's trying to piece together a new, more flexible health care system, relying on new partnerships and better technology, including telemedicine. If it works, Paradise could become a template for how to deliver health care to rural America, not just those communities hit by disaster, but areas that have seen hospitals close and the numbers of doctors dwindle. Former Sen. Thad Cochran died on Thursday morning in Oxford, Miss. He was 81. Cochran served as the Senate Appropriations Committee chairman, most recently from 2015 until April of 2018, and helped direct millions of dollars to his home state in his 45 years in Congress. He stepped down last spring as his health deteriorated, and Sen. Cindy Hyde-Smith was selected as his replacement. The GOP senator was a throwback from a more genteel era of American politics, rarely engaging the brutal fights and pitched partisanship of today's modern-day Senate. In his farewell speech last year, Cochran reminisced of serving in Congress "with nine presidents during times of conflict and peace." On this day 47 years ago, Richard Nixon became the first U.S. president to visit Moscow. During his 105-minute meeting with Leonid Brezhnev, then-secretary of the Communist Party, they discussed the possibility of slowing the nuclear arms race between the two superpowers.

That evening, Nixon and his wife, Pat, attended a banquet at the Kremlin where Soviet President Nikolai Podgorny and Nixon spoke and made toasts to peace. Four days later, they signed the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty, which limited the U.S. and Soviet Union to 200 antiballistic missiles each.

Nixon then flew back to the U.S. to prepare for his 1972 reelection campaign. (Nixon is pictured shaking hands with Brezhnev and Dmitry Polyansky is at the center) üì∑AP

Democrat Pete Buttigieg officially kicked off his presidential bid on Sunday, starting a new phase of the campaign as one of the main candidates to watch just three months after he announced an exploratory committee to little fanfare. House Democrats‚Äô bid to seize Trump‚Äôs tax returns will come with some serious legal risk to themselves. Lawmakers are concerned that even if they get the president‚Äôs filings, the documents will still be protected by strict confidentiality laws; it is a felony, punishable by up to five years in prison, to improperly disclose private tax information. But there are ways around the roadblock, and lawmakers say they will likely take some time to examine Trump‚Äôs filings behind closed doors before making anything public. That means there will be a period when House Ways and Means Chairman Richard Neal and other Democrats will have finally seen the president‚Äôs long-hidden taxes, but won‚Äôt be able to talk about them. In their forthcoming book, POLITICO‚Äôs Jake Sherman and Anna Palmer report how President Donald Trump conspired late last year with Reps. Mark Meadows and Jim Jordan of the conservative House Freedom Caucus to initiate the longest federal government shutdown in U.S. history. ‚ÄúMonths after the 34-day standoff that followed, the full story of how the president was pushed into the shutdown is a lesson in how to take the reins in Trump‚Äôs Washington. The lawmakers around Trump who wanted a shutdown knew exactly how to bring the president around to their side: threaten that others might perceive him as weak and push that threat around Capitol Hill and, eventually, all the way to Fox News. It helped to have a man on the inside, too‚Äîin this case, acting chief of staff Mick Mulvaney. As Meadows was about to find out, following this playbook was enough to get inside the head of the most powerful man in Washington, and use him to get what Meadows and his allies wanted.‚Äù Link in bio for the full behind-the-scenes account.

Via @politicomag: Food and politics have always had a complicated relationship. On one hand, food is a powerful political tool. Eating and drinking are ways in which political candidates reveal their humanity, their common touch. And so they hobnob over barbecue with voters in South Carolina, livestream from their kitchens and Instagram their calorie bombs at the Iowa State Fair. ‚ÄúDining together makes you much more relatable, and I think people want a president they feel they could relate to,‚Äù says Terry Sullivan, who managed Marco Rubio‚Äôs presidential bid in 2016. Banal as eating can be, though, sharing food and drink is also surprisingly intimate, and it touches on so many taboos, cultural stereotypes and straight up bodily awkwardness that it leaves candidates vulnerable, opening them up to social media mockery.
üî∏
Nothing incredibly viral has happened with this year‚Äôs crop of candidates and their meals yet. But especially at this early point in the race, people are poking around for clues about who each 2020 contender really is. We look for meaning in their food choices ‚Äî perhaps hoping to discover how they act in those human moments when the barriers come down, but also, recognizing that the barriers might still be up, to discover what their meal choices might say about their politics, or strategy. Link in bio to learn more about why we‚Äôre so obsessed with how politicians eat. üì∑ AP Photo

Via @politicomag: Many of Bernie Sanders' supporters and advisers think he should talk about his 1988 endorsement of Jesse Jackson more often. Gun maker Remington can be sued over how it marketed the Bushmaster rifle used to kill 20 children and six educators at Sandy Hook Elementary School in 2012, the Associated Press reported. Justices in the  Connecticut Supreme Court issued a 4-3 decision that reinstated a wrongful death lawsuit and overturned a lower court ruling that the lawsuit was prohibited by a 2005 federal law that shields gun manufacturers from liability in most cases when their products are used in crimes. The plaintiffs include a survivor and relatives of nine people killed in the massacre. They argue the AR-15-style rifle used by shooter Adam Lanza is too dangerous for the public and Remington glorified the weapon in marketing it to young people. Remington has denied wrongdoing and previously insisted it can‚Äôt be sued under the federal law. Link in bio for the full story üì∏: Getty Images

The college admissions scandal revealed this week raises the question of why it's OK for wealthy parents to donate millions to get their child admitted to an elite school, but they can't pay a coach to slip in a kid as a recruited "athlete." Paul Manafort is going to prison for seven-and-a-half years. It's the longest sentence by far for anyone ensnared in special counsel Robert Mueller‚Äôs nearly two-year-old probe. A new policy will largely bar transgender troops and military recruits from transitioning to another sex, and require most individuals to serve in their birth gender, the AP reported. President Trump sent his annual budget vision to Congress on Monday, starting a new battle over how to fund the government that sets up the nation for an even more destructive shutdown when money runs out later this year. Breaking: Paul Manafort gets 47 months in prison for financial fraud, a much lighter sentence than many anticipated. His sentence was handed down by U.S. District Court Judge T.S. Ellis III in Alexandria, V.A. Ellis signaled that he wasn't going to send Manafort away for what could have amounted to a life sentence, saying that he found the guidelines in the case (which called for roughly 20 and 24 years) "excessive" and that Manafort "lived an otherwise blameless life." His sentence is the longest to date for a Trump associate tangled in special counsel Robert Mueller‚Äôs Russia investigation. Rand Paul said over the weekend that he'll vote against President Trump's emergency declaration, so here's what happens next üëâ His vote pretty much ensures that the Senate will join the House in voting down the president's unilateral action. Trump will then turn around and veto the measure that disapproves of his declaration. Congress won't have the votes to overturn his veto, though. It would take 290 votes in the House to overturn a presidential veto, which would mean 55 Republicans would need to vote with all Democrats, and that isn't happening. There aren't 67 senators who will vote to overturn Trump's veto, either. It seems exceedingly unlikely  that the president will voluntarily decide to rescind his emergency declaration, as some Republicans have suggested he should. There's more in today's Playbook, link in bio for the latest. üì∏ Getty Images

The White House has scoffed at Cohen‚Äôs testimony and said he cannot be trusted. Link in bio for the full story. üì∏:Getty Images

The House voted to overturn Trump's national emergency declaration. Every Democrat voted in favor, along with 13 Republicans. The unprecedented vote to block Trump‚Äôs emergency order is the first piece of Democrats‚Äô strategy to halt the president's attempt to spend billions of dollars on a border wall without Congress‚Äôs approval (which both parties acknowledge is likely to land in the Supreme Court.) The Senate will vote on the resolution in the coming weeks, where just four GOP votes are needed approve it and send it to the president's desk for his first veto. Speaker Nancy Pelosi and her deputies have spent weeks pitching the measure as a constitutional duty, rather than as a partisan ploy by newly emboldened Democrats who seem eager to humiliate Trump. Republicans in the House will largely fall in line behind Trump, under immense pressure from GOP leaders, White House aides, and the president himself. Link in bio for the full story. üì∏: AP Photo

President Trump has a blind spot in making a deal with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un. He's planning to pitch Kim on a vision of a modern and wealthy North Korea to convince him to give up his nuclear arsenal, but a law Trump himself signed into law basically prevents that because of North Korea‚Äôs human right abuses. It would be up to Congress to repeal the 2017 law in order for any American company to significantly invest in North Korea‚Äîand that‚Äôs unlikely, without a deal that addresses human rights. Link in bio for what else you need to know before Trump's meeting with Kim in Hanoi. üì∏ Getty Images

Republican Mark Harris announced on Tuesday that he will not run in the new election for North Carolina‚Äôs 9th Congressional District, citing his compromised health. Hillary Clinton said this week that she has little faith in President Trump‚Äôs ability to negotiate for North Korean denuclearization, and speculated that any claims of victory will be like putting ‚Äúlipstick on a pig.‚Äù The former secretary of State told journalist Tina Brown in a podcast episode released Tuesday that ahead of Trump‚Äôs summit with North Korea‚Äôs Kim Jong Un, ‚ÄúI have serious doubts that whatever [Trump] claims will be actually achieved.‚Äù Link in bio for more of Clinton's remarks. üì∏ Getty Images

Michael Cohen is speaking before the Senate Intelligence Committee Tuesday for the first day in a three-day marathon of testimony for President Trump‚Äôs former attorney and fixer. Cohen plans to offer up a document to lawmakers that he claims will show the Trump engaged in criminal conduct related to a hush-money payment to porn star Stormy Daniels, according to a person familiar with his planned congressional testimony. Even if special counsel Robert Mueller finishes his work without filing new charges, President Trump and his associates won‚Äôt be in the clear. Mueller is far from the only threat to the president, his family and aides. Federal prosecutors in New York are examining Trump‚Äôs 2016 campaign, inauguration and businesses. Congress has given the Justice Department dozens of hearing transcripts that could contain lies told under oath. State and local prosecutors have reportedly prepped new charges that can‚Äôt be erased with a presidential pardon. And a slate of sealed indictments sit in the Washington, D.C., federal courthouse, raising the prospect that some in Trump‚Äôs circle may have already been indicted and just don‚Äôt know it. More than 100 young people stormed Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell‚Äôs office urging him to back an aggressive campaign to confront climate change. The youth advocates from the Sunrise Movement held signs that said, ‚ÄúMitch, Look us in the eyes‚Äù and ‚ÄúOil and Gas Money or Save Our Lives," among other messages. The protest comes as McConnell is planning a vote on the Green New Deal resolution in an effort to highlight Democratic divisions over the ambitious set of goals, but the youth say he should be held accountable for failing to put forward any strategy of his own to do anything about the issue. Sen. Elizabeth Warren announced her presidential campaign will shun fundraising through some of the old-fashioned means: dinners, donor calls and cocktail parties. The self-imposed restrictions allow Warren to distinguish herself from the field at a time when candidates are in a mad race for small dollar donations. Link in bio for more. üì∏ Getty Images

Vice President Mike Pence posed for a photo with Venezuela's self-proclaimed interim president Juan Guaido (left) and Colombia's President Ivan Duque (center) after a meeting concerning Venezuela at the Foreign Ministry in Bogota, Colombia. Bernie Sanders spent at least $342,000 on private jet travel in the last two years, while making wealth inequality and climate change targets of his 2020 campaign. In his campaign launch video last week, Sanders singled out the fossil fuel industry for criticism, listing it among the special interests he planned to take on. President Trump lashed out at director Spike Lee on Monday, calling the filmmaker out after he used his Oscars acceptance speech Sunday night to urge viewers to vote against Trump and ‚Äúbe on the right side of history‚Äù in the 2020 election. ‚ÄúBe nice if Spike Lee could read his notes, or better yet not have to use notes at all, when doing his racist hit on your President, who has done more for African Americans (Criminal Justice Reform, Lowest Unemployment numbers in History, Tax Cuts, etc.) than almost any other Pres!‚Äù Trump wrote in a tweet. Though the Academy Awards ceremony is usually a time to celebrate achievements in film, politics often finds a way onto the stage and across the airwaves. Link in bio for a look at past political happenings at the Oscars ahead of tonight's show. üì∑ AP Photo

Nomiki Konst is casting herself as the Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of the New York public advocate‚Äôs race, and she readily acknowledges that her background is politically unconventional. Like Ocasio-Cortez, Konst has not risen through traditional Democratic channels. She identifies as a Democratic Socialist, and her campaign depicts her as one in a movement of millennial women finding their voices. Aides say her journey has naturally culminated in a run for an office that‚Äôs second in line to the mayor of the biggest city in America. But for someone campaigning for a job to keep fellow city leaders honest, Konst's own personal history is hard to pin down. The 35-year-old TV pundit wandered from Tucson to Buffalo to Florida to Los Angeles to New York City, from one cause to the next. Certain things are clear: she spent two years roving the country for The Young Turks, an openly ideological news outlet that is, in many ways, the left‚Äôs answer to Breitbart. And she can credibly lay claim to being a social media ‚Äúinfluencer,‚Äù with a robust Twitter following of 84,000. Link in bio for more on Nomiki Konst. üì∑ Stefan Jeremiah

On this day in 1868, the House voted to impeach a sitting president for the first time in U.S. history. It was Andrew Johnson.
üî∏
The main charge against him was that he had violated the Tenure of Office Act, which Congress passed in 1867 to protect Edwin Stanton, a hard-line secretary of war. Johnson, a Southern Democrat who had remained loyal to the Union during the Civil War, had fired Stanton and tried to replace him with Ulysses S. Grant, commanding general of the U.S. Army.
üî∏
However, even though the House voted to impeach him, the Senate later failed to convict the president by a narrow margin. On three successive occasions, 35 senators voted ‚Äúguilty‚Äù and 19 voted ‚Äúnot guilty.‚Äù Since the Constitution requires a 2/3 majority for conviction, Johnson escaped being ousted from office by just one vote. Link in bio for more from @politicomag about how a difficult, racist, stubborn president was removed from power ‚Äî if not from office. üì∑ AP Photo

Karl Racine, co-chair of the national Democratic Attorneys General Association, is playing a little-noticed but hugely influential role in fighting the Trump administration at the polls, in the courts and in the news media. While the public has been mesmerized by the president's legal troubles, Racine has been quietly building out Democrats‚Äô ability to check the executive branch at the state level. Without much notice, he has quietly emerged as perhaps the single most important player in restoring Democratic clout in America‚Äôs legal system.
üî∏
As D.C. attorney general, Racine is leading the emoluments suit against the president over foreign governments' patronage of Washington's Trump International Hotel, along with Maryland AG Brian Frosh. As co-chair of DAGA, Racine has helped coordinate the strategies behind the lawsuits suing the Trump administration over issues including the separation of families at the southern border, upholding the Affordable Care Act and protecting DACA recipients. And more substantial yet, Racine was the architect of one of the least-discussed but most far-reaching results of November‚Äôs elections: Democrats winning a majority of the nation‚Äôs attorney general positions. All of that has put him on a trajectory for ‚Ä¶ well, what exactly? Link in bio for the full story from @politicomag. üì∑ AP Photo

A federal judge should consider giving former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort a sentence that would send him to prison for at least 17 and a half years, special counsel Robert Mueller said in a court filing made public Saturday. That could amount to a life sentence for the 69-year-old Manafort, who became one of the most prominent targets of Mueller‚Äôs probe into alleged collusion between the Trump presidential campaign and Russia. Manafort faces a pair of sentencing hearings in the coming weeks in Virginia and in Washington where judges will determine what punishment he should face in two separate criminal cases brought by Mueller‚Äôs office involving tax fraud, bank fraud, unregistered lobbying for a foreign government and witness tampering. Link in bio for the full story. üì∑ Getty Images

Via @politicomag: Beto O‚ÄôRourke is now on the precipice of running for president with ‚Äúlosing Senate candidate‚Äù as the most impressive line on his r√©sum√©. But it was how he chose to run that campaign last year that sets him apart from his potential 2020 Democratic rivals. He didn‚Äôt care about moving opinions. Instead, his campaign amounted to a massive bet on a strategy of mobilizing infrequent voters instead of trying to win over dependable ones. Everything may be bigger in Texas, but when the three-term El Paso congressman set out to challenge GOP Sen. Ted Cruz, there had been no reason to expect his campaign would reach such mammoth proportions. (It ended up with a staff similar in size to Trump‚Äôs entire national organization in 2016.) Link in bio for a look inside O‚ÄôRourke‚Äôs radical campaign strategy. üì∑ Tamir Kalifa for POLITICO Magazine

Trump announced that he will nominate the current Ambassador to Canada Kelly Knight Craft as his next United Nations ambassador. If confirmed, Craft would fill a vacancy left after Nikki Haley resigned and State Department spokeswoman Heather Nauert withdrew from consideration. Craft is a Kentucky native and the wife of billionaire coal baron Joe Craft, who has donated $1 million to Trump's inauguration. The couple served on the finance committee for Trump's inaugural. Joe Craft donated more than $1.6 since 2011 to campaigns and super PACs connected to McConnell, who praised the nomination as an "exceptional choice." During an interview with us, Kelly Knight Craft did not rule out interest in the post. "I am committed to serving the president," Craft said. "I am committed at the moment to Canada," she said. Link in bio for the full story. üì∏: Getty Images

Chance the Rapper is going political in his hometown: Chicago. President Trump is eagerly anticipating his second summit with Kim Jong Un next week. He's been touting their ‚Äúreally meaningful‚Äù relationship and insisting North Korea's strongman is ready to give up his nuclear arsenal. But many, including several of the president‚Äôs top advisers, are less excited. Some have expressed worry not only that the summit in Hanoi may not yield big results, but also that Trump, eager to declare victory on the world stage, could make big concessions in exchange for empty promises of denuclearization. Colorado Gov. Jared Polis called the possibility of a federal crackdown on legalized marijuana an ‚Äúexistential threat‚Äù to the cannabis industry in his state. While there aren‚Äôt signs that the federal government plans to ramp up prosecution efforts against Colorado's legal marijuana industry, if there were, the Democratic governor said, it would be ‚Äúof great concern,‚Äù speaking at @politico.live's State Solutions Conference on Friday. ‚ÄúWe support a regulatory approach to hemp just like any other crop,‚Äù said Polis, showing off his business card, printed on hemp paper. Recreational marijuana use was made legal in Colorado in 2012, but since the drug remains illegal based on federal law, it puts otherwise legal operators in Colorado in constant jeopardy of being arrested by federal authorities. The House plans to vote Tuesday on legislation to block President Donald Trump‚Äôs attempt to circumvent Congress to fund his border wall, Speaker Nancy Pelosi said Friday. The privileged resolution targeting the national emergency declaration is expected to easily pass the House. It then will be voted on in the Senate within 18 days. üì∏ Getty Images

Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan isn‚Äôt ruling out mounting a 2020 Republican primary challenge against President Donald Trump. While he cautioned that he was sworn in for his second term as governor just a month ago, he didn‚Äôt deny that he‚Äôs being courted for a GOP primary run by Trump critics. ‚ÄúI would say I‚Äôm being approached from a lot of different people, and I guess the best way to put it is I haven‚Äôt thrown them out of my office,‚Äù he told CBS News‚Äô Ed O‚ÄôKeefe in an interview that aired Wednesday morning. President Trump‚Äôs declaration of a national emergency to fund his border wall has come under bipartisan criticism. Whether he‚Äôs able to hold off a congressional push to block the move will soon become clear. House Democrats are expected to pass a formal resolution of disapproval of Trump‚Äôs declaration, which would then head to the Senate floor where only a simple majority is needed for passage. If four GOP senators join Democrats, they could pass legislation to block the president. Although many GOP senators criticized Trump for declaring a national emergency, few have said whether they would break with the president. Here are some of the crucial voters to keep an eye on. Watch our Instagram story for more.

North Carolina‚Äôs state board of elections voted to order a new election in the state‚Äôs disputed 9th Congressional District. This is the last unresolved race from the 2018 midterms. (No winner was declared back then amid fraud allegations). The board voted to call a new House race after hearing testimony that the November election between Republican Mark Harris and Democrat Dan McCready was tainted by a scheme to collect and mark voters‚Äô absentee ballots. Harris called for a new election earlier Thursday, reversing weeks of GOP resistance to a new North Carolina race after state officials said that Harris' campaign attorney withheld documents relevant to the investigation. Harris‚Äô campaign attorney said it was not intentional. Link in bio for the full story. üì∏: AP Photo

New Jersey‚Äôs Democratic establishment is notoriously fractious, but it‚Äôs in lockstep behind Sen. Cory Booker‚Äôs presidential run. Phil Murphy, First Lady Tammy Murphy, Sen. Bob Menendez, Newark Mayor Ras Baraka and all 21 Democratic county chairs. It‚Äôs up to William Barr to decide how much of Robert Mueller‚Äôs final report becomes public. So until then, President Trump is playing nice. The approach comes as Trump‚Äôs inner circle is signaling that they believe the special counsel has essentially completed his work. Link in bio for the latest. üì∏ Getty Images

In emotional testimony, the son of North Carolina Republican Mark Harris said he warned his father about the absentee ballot strategy used by Leslie McCrae Dowless, the political operative now at the center of an election fraud scandal in the state's 9th Congressional District. Speaker Nancy Pelosi is throwing her muscle behind a legislative effort to block Trump‚Äôs national emergency declaration. Democrats will introduce legislation Friday to terminate the emergency proclamation and Pelosi is urging House colleagues on both sides of the aisle to support the resolution, according to a letter we obtained. "I write to invite all Members of Congress to cosponsor Congressman Joaquin Castro‚Äôs privileged resolution to terminate this emergency declaration," Pelosi wrote, noting that the House will "move swiftly to pass this bill." Trump says he hasn't thought about firing Director of National Intelligence Dan Coats, despite several reports that the president is frustrated with the chief intelligence official. During the hearing, Coats broke with the president on several critical foreign policy fronts like telling lawmakers that North Korea isn‚Äôt likely to ‚Äúcompletely give up its nuclear weapons and production capabilities.‚Äù He also appeared to contradict Trump‚Äôs stance on ISIS, saying that the terrorist group remains a forceful presence in Iraq and Syria, even as the president is preparing to withdraw troops from the region. Link in bio for the full story. üì∏: AP Photo

Trump‚Äôs former personal attorney and fixer Michael Cohen will appear before the House Oversight Committee for a public hearing on Feb. 27, Chairman Elijah Cummings announced. The notice came hours after a judge granted Cohen a two-month reprieve on reporting to prison while he continues to recover from shoulder surgery and prepares to testify before a total of three congressional panels. Last December, Cohen was sentenced to three years in prison following his guilty plea to a variety of fraud charges as well as charges that he conspired to arrange illegal donations to Trump‚Äôs 2016 presidential campaign in the form of unreported payments to women claiming to have had sexual affairs with the candidate. The Oversight Committee said the scope of Cohen‚Äôs public testimony would be limited to Trump‚Äôs ‚Äúpayoffs, financial disclosures, compliance with campaign finance laws, business practices, and other matters.‚Äù Link in bio for the full story. üì∏ AP Photo

Former President Barack Obama joined the Golden State Warriors‚Äô Stephen Curry in Oakland, California, on Tuesday for the first national meeting of the My Brother's Keeper Alliance. Bernie Sanders' 2020 campaign is off to an impressive start. The Vermont senator crushed other Democratic candidates in his first day of online fundraising, and boasted social media stats that easily outstripped his competition, too. There are signs that foreign state actors are driving at least some of the activity in a wide-ranging social media disinformation campaign aimed at Democratic 2020 candidates. Roger Stone scored a small legal victory last Friday, but it only took him four days to blow it.
Now, even his friends expect the longtime Donald Trump associate will get hit with a sweeping gag order preventing him from commenting about his case on Thursday at an emergency hearing in Washington, D.C. U.S. District Judge Amy Berman Jackson called the hearing in the wake of him posting a threatening message about her on Instagram. Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis wants to leverage a tax incentive championed by Trump to launch a five-fold expansion of charter schools in the state. The DeSantis budget proposed linking Florida‚Äôs Schools of Hope program to federal "opportunity zones"created by Trump‚Äôs $1.5 billion tax plan. Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Elizabeth Warren rolled out a plan that would tax millionaires to fund free child care for millions of low-income children and affordable care for others. "In the wealthiest country on the planet, access to affordable and high-quality child care and early education should be a right, not a privilege reserved for the rich," Warren wrote in a Medium post. On this day in 1942, President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed an executive order removing 112,000 Japanese-Americans ‚Äî most of them U.S. citizens ‚Äî from their homes across the country to be relocated in internment camps. The order came 10 weeks after the Pearl Harbor bombing, and many political leaders suspected that Americans of Japanese descent were spying on behalf of the far eastern country. For the next two and a half years, Japanese-Americans endured difficult living conditions and poor treatment by military guards. FDR's order essentially authorized relocation of Japanese-Americans from the entire West Coast, and the U.S. Census Bureau helped by providing confidential data on neighborhood residents. In 1944, the Supreme Court upheld its constitutionality 6-3. Link in bio for more from our This Day in Politics series. üì∏ AP Photo

A trove of emails offers a rare glimpse into the working relationship between Mitch McConnell and Elaine Chao ‚Äì one of the most powerful couples in Washington. It‚Äôs official: Bernie Sanders is running for president again, this time as a heavyweight candidate against a crowded field of liberals. States are facing a new danger as legal marijuana spreads across the country: Explosions and fires at cannabis factories. The industry's lack of proper safety standards is sending workers to the hospital with severe burns. In the 33 states where the drug is legal for medical or recreational use, at least 10 fires or explosions have occurred in the past five years at facilities that extract hash oil used in edible products. Nearly all resulted in serious injuries for production-line staff. Most of the states where marijuana is legal offer no safety and health guidance for the new industry. Link in bio for more on the new problem for legal weed. üì∏¬†AP Photos

The U.S. is trying desperately to isolate Iran. But on Sunday, Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif seized the stage of the world‚Äôs premier security conference. He held the audience of power-brokers rapt for nearly 40 minutes as he thrashed the Trump administration, fired a pointed demand at Europe to do more to protect their nuclear deal, and generally painted a portrait of Tehran‚Äôs worldview that at times drew chuckles for defying reality. The striking performance, which quickly became the most talked-about presentation at the annual Munich Security Conference, came three days after senior Trump administration officials convened a global conference about the Middle East in Warsaw, where they had sought to rally international sentiment against Iran. But Zarif‚Äôs speech in Munich and his aggressive replies in the question-and-answer session showed the Tehran government utterly unbowed. Link in bio for the full story. üì∑ AP Photo

The national effort to curb the opioid crisis faces another big potential obstacle ‚Äî insurers who won‚Äôt pay for less-addictive ways to control patients‚Äô pain.
üî∏
Patients seeking other pain treatment options often find that their insurers won‚Äôt foot the bill or are forcing them to jump through maddening hoops to get coverage. Experts in and out of government worry that this will make it more difficult to reverse the deadly opioid crisis that killed more than 47,000 people nationwide in 2017, even as doctors cut back on opioid prescribing and state and federal governments step up efforts to prevent and treat addiction.
üî∏
‚ÄúThe epidemic isn‚Äôt just about how easy opioids have been to come by. It‚Äôs also about how hard it is to access alternatives,‚Äù said Caleb Alexander, co-director of Johns Hopkins University‚Äôs Center for Drug Safety and Effectiveness. ‚ÄúNo one ever died of an overdose of physical therapy.‚Äù Link in bio for the full story.

State Department spokeswoman Heather Nauert has withdrawn herself from consideration to become the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, the State Department confirmed on Saturday. ‚ÄúI am grateful to President Trump and Secretary [of State Mike] Pompeo for the trust they placed in me for considering me for the position of U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations. However, the past two months have been grueling for my family and therefore it is in the best interest of my family that I withdraw my name from consideration,‚Äù Nauert said in a statement. The move leaves President Donald Trump without an ambassador to the United Nations amid growing questions about the strength of U.S. leadership on the global stage. The Border Patrol is facing a recruitment crisis. The law enforcement agency's struggles to attract and keep agents present a seldom-discussed impediment to President Donald Trump‚Äôs efforts to lock down the U.S.-Mexico border ‚Äî one that the White House is reluctant to acknowledge.
üî∏
Shortly after taking office, Trump signed an executive order that called for the hiring of 5,000 agents. More recently, his administration pushed a proposal that calls for 2,750 more agents, law enforcement officers and staff. But Border Patrol can‚Äôt hire enough people to fill jobs that were available before. Even as Congress provides funding to hire 21,370 agents, the patrol is more than 1,800 agents short of that mark.
üî∏
The struggle to recruit and retain Border Patrol agents predates the Trump administration. The number of agents peaked at 21,444 in fiscal year 2011, and since then has mostly trended downward. U.S. Customs and Border Protection, the parent agency to Border Patrol, consistently ranks near the bottom of an annual federal survey of employee satisfaction. Link in bio for the full story. üì∑ Getty Images

Sen. Amy Klobuchar leapt into the 2020 presidential race Sunday, becoming the first Midwestern state official to join the field taking on President Donald Trump. Klobuchar used the nearby Mississippi River as a symbol for her ‚Äúhomegrown,‚Äù heartland campaign, and she has prepared a playbook for 2020 focusing on the type of Midwestern voters who have abandoned the Democratic Party ‚Äî though not Klobuchar herself ‚Äî in recent years. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have a political machine. I don‚Äôt come from money. But what I do have is this: I have grit,‚Äù Klobuchar said in the speech. ‚ÄúI have family. I have friends. I have neighbors. I have all of you who are willing to come out in the middle of the winter, all of you who took the time to watch us today, all of you who are willing to stand up and say people matter.‚Äù Link in bio for the full story. üì∑ AP Photo and Getty Images

Talks to avert another government shutdown are stalled. The negotiations abruptly fell apart over the weekend, raising the risk of another shuttering of services, a stopgap funding bill or a declaration by President Donald Trump of a national emergency at the southern border. Efforts to hammer out a border security package have cratered because of disagreements over interior enforcement within the U.S., detention beds and paying for a border barrier, leaving lawmakers in the same place they‚Äôve been for months. There was radio silence midday Sunday after Republican and Democratic negotiators had passed offers back and forth for more than a week.
üî∏
The faltering discussions came after lawmakers entered the weekend feeling optimistic about their chances of crafting a bipartisan deal. Negotiators are under pressure to reach an agreement by Monday to fund the government past Feb. 15, in order to allow the House and Senate sufficient time to review and vote on the proposal. But even if the conference committee fails and Congress considers a stopgap funding bill, Republicans and Democrats may still clash over the particulars of any continuing resolution, a form of appropriations legislation that Democrats may use to restrict unilateral action by Trump on the border. Link in bio for the full story. üì∑ Getty Images

Former Democratic Rep. John D. Dingell Jr., the longest-serving member of Congress died Thursday at 92. The cause of death was prostate cancer. Rep. The 35-day partial government shutdown cost the U.S. economy about $3 billion in forgone economic activity that won't be recovered, the Congressional Budget Office said in a new report Monday. Leading climate scientists and meteorologists are banking on a new strategy for talking about climate change: Take the politics out of it. At the American Meteorological Society‚Äôs annual meeting this month, conference attendees spoke about the need for a new lexicon to educate the public about climate change at a time when elected leaders are doubling down on denying that it is happening at all.
üî∏
Their hope is to persuade the small but powerful minority that stands in the way of new policies to mitigate climate change‚Äôs worst long-term effects ‚Äî as well as the people who vote for them ‚Äî that something needs to be done or their own livelihoods and health will be at stake. That means avoiding the politically charged phrase ‚Äúclimate change,‚Äù stopping talk about who or what is most responsible, and focusing instead on what is happening and how unusual it is.
üî∏
The new language taking root is meant to instill this sense of urgency about climate change in ways to which everyday citizens can relate ‚Äî without directly blaming it on human activity: The spring blossoms keep coming earlier; seasonal allergies are worsening and lasting longer; extreme heat is upending the kids‚Äô summer camp schedule; crops are drying up or washing away at alarming rates. And wherever possible, climate specialists said, they are trying to explain the more frequent and deadly weather events in purely historical terms. Link in bio for the full story. üì∑ Getty Images

Kamala Harris formally launched her 2020 presidential bid Sunday with a raucous hometown rally that honed in on two broad themes: truth and civility. ‚ÄúAs we embark on this campaign, I will tell you this: I am not perfect. Lord knows I am not perfect,‚Äù said the California Democrat. ‚ÄúBut I will always speak with decency and moral clarity and treat all people with dignity and respect. With the stately backdrop of Oakland City Hall, where a preacher bellowed, a gospel choir sang and ‚Äúartists of the black diaspora‚Äù performed, Harris‚Äô dual message underscored her candidacy as one of both a Democratic uniter and a principled leader tough enough to stand up to the Trump White House, whose administration she said was failing the public.

The U.S. spends $3.5 trillion a year on health ‚Äî and still has one of the most unequal health systems in the world.  But a new medical school in post-genocide Rwanda may hold some lessons. The University of Global Health Equity, located on a small hilltop in the poor farming village of Butaro, aims to transform both medical education and medical care for the rural poor in central Africa and to serve as a model for more equitable health care around the globe.
üî∏
Butaro is lifetimes away from the bustling cities that medical schools and their students gravitate toward, but it‚Äôs exactly what the university‚Äôs founders had in mind when it came time to pick a site. Most people in the world live in similar rural areas, eking out a living on meager sums. To bring them health care, the medical school staff believe, you have to go where they are and immerse yourself in their lives. You must understand what their houses look like, what they eat, how they work and how they care for their children.
üî∏
‚ÄúOur vision is a world where every individual, no matter where they are, who they are and where they live, can lead a healthy and productive life,‚Äù said Agnes Binagwaho, a Rwandan physician and vice chancellor of the university that opens its permanent campus this month. ‚ÄúOur mission is to radically change education, health education, so that we impact the way health care is delivered around the world.‚Äù Link in bio for the full story. üì∑ Getty Images

The longest government shutdown in U.S. history came to an end Friday after President Donald Trump and Congress agreed to temporarily reopen shuttered federal agencies without providing any money for the president‚Äôs border wall. "Now true, the people might have to pay a little bit of interest, but the idea that it's paycheck or zero is not a really valid idea," he continued. Democrats are pouncing on Ross for his remarks, along with other Trump officials who have compared the shutdown to a ‚Äúvacation" or a ‚Äúglitch.‚Äù As about 800,000 federal workers are bracing for their second missed paycheck, the White House is facing an intensifying backlash over seemingly out-of-touch comments from Trump‚Äôs group of largely wealthy advisers. Link in bio for the full story. üì∏ AP Photo

Venezuela's anti-government protesters celebrated Wednesday as Juan Guaid√≥, head of Venezuela's opposition-run congress, declared himself interim president. President Trump's disapproval rating is at an all-time high, according to our latest poll. Reps. Ayanna Pressley and Jahana Hayes in 2018 became the first African-American women elected to Congress from Massachusetts and Connecticut, respectively. ‚ÄúWe ran to make a difference.
