Today marks 46 years since the Roe v. Wade U.S. Supreme Court decision, which recognized that the constitutional right to privacy encompasses a woman‚Äôs right to decide to end her pregnancy.

In the early 1970s, Norma ‚ÄúJane Roe‚Äù McCorvey (pictured) challenged Texas‚Äô abortion laws and instituted federal action against Dallas county district attorney Henry Wade. And on January 22, 1973, the Supreme Court ruled 7-2 that criminalizing abortion was unconstitutional, overruling the state‚Äôs ban on abortions that were not necessary to save a woman‚Äôs life.

However, Alabama recently became the first state in the nation to formally recognize ‚Äúthe rights of unborn children, including the right to life‚Äù in its constitution ‚Äî making it possible for the state to ban abortion entirely if Roe v. Wade is overturned.

This measure is the latest in a multiyear crusade by anti-abortion groups to enact state laws that could present a legal challenge to Roe vs. Wade when the moment is right. And with conservative Justice Brett Kavanaugh freshly installed on the Supreme Court, that moment may be coming sooner than many expected. Link in our bio to read more about Roe v. Wade's upcoming challenges. üì∑Getty

Exclusive: The GOP has reached landmark agreement to boost small-dollar fundraising. The new platform called Patriot Pass will aim to close the financial gap that devastated Republicans during the midterms. With the deal, President Trump‚Äôs political team and top Republican officials hope to create a rival to ActBlue, the Democratic online fundraising tool that raised over $700 million in small-dollar donations for Dems in the 2018 campaign. The GOP has struggled in the past to create such a unified system. Link in bio for more on the new Republican fundraising plan. üì∏ Getty Images

Rep. Mark Meadows ‚Äî who many people, even those in Washington, couldn‚Äôt pick out of a lineup ‚Äî might be one of the nation‚Äôs most powerful lawmakers. Four sources with knowledge of their relationship said President Donald Trump talks to the North Carolina Republican more than he does with many of his senior aides. They sometimes spend an hour-plus on the phone together or speak more than once per day.
üî∏
Meadows has used that access to push Trump toward stances aligned with the ascendant House Freedom Caucus, the hard-line conservative and libertarian conference founded in 2015 that Meadows chairs. And last month, the three-term congressman managed to engineer what has become the longest-running government shutdown ever ‚Äî persuading the president to stand firm on his border wall demand right as the partial closure was on the brink of being avoided. Link in bio for the full story. üì∑ Getty Images

Kamala Harris is officially running for president. The former California attorney general and San Francisco district attorney who was elected to the Senate two years ago, made the announcement on ABC‚Äôs ‚ÄúGood Morning America‚Äù on Monday. She's the first African-American to enter the 2020 presidential race and the first black senator from California. Harris also released a video teasing the formal start of her campaign at a rally this Sunday in Oakland, California, Harris‚Äô birthplace and the city that cultivated her political rise. Link in bio for more on the early stages of her campaign. üì∏ AP Photo

Republicans have tried to drive a wedge between the duo for more than a month now. But House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer are sticking together through the government shutdown fight. By setting a model of unity, they have kept moderates in their caucuses from breaking ranks and underscored how difficult it will be for President Donald Trump to get Democrats to fold.
üî∏
Though the Democratic leaders came up in the House together and represent liberal coastal areas, their approach to politics often differs. Schumer tends to slouch when the cameras are turned off and brings leftovers in a Tupperware into the Senate each week. Pelosi has become something of a fashion icon, clad in tailored pantsuits or dresses, often with matching high heels. He fashions himself a messaging guru and is known for ingratiating himself with his members. She hails from a Baltimore political dynasty and is more of a blunt operator.
üî∏
But with a combined seven decades of service on Capitol Hill, the two are the experienced, old-school pols many Democrats want leading them against a volatile president. That‚Äôs even as Schumer and Pelosi, 68 and 78 respectively, diverge in some ways from their party, which is more diverse and younger than ever. Link in bio for the full story. üì∑ AP Photo

Federal and state governments are pumping billions of dollars into addiction care to fight the opioid crisis. But industry oversight hasn‚Äôt kept up, leaving patients vulnerable to fraud, abuse and ineffective treatment.
üî∏
There are few tools to help patients navigate a maze of treatment options that include both inpatient and outpatient medical facilities ‚Äî as well as ‚Äúsober living‚Äù or ‚Äúrecovery homes,‚Äù which have roots in abstinence and faith. And it‚Äôs immensely more complicated for patients with little money.
üî∏
Meanwhile, the opioid epidemic remains the biggest American public health crisis in decades, arguably since the emergence of AIDS. It kills about 130 people a day. Link in bio for the full story.

This week in review: High drama gripped the Capitol as lawmakers attempted to conduct regular business amid the bleakest week yet of the partial government shutdown. Swipe üëàfor @smahaskey‚Äôs shots from the Capitol this week. 
Rep. Adam Schiff talks to reporters, after President Trump canceled Speaker Nancy Pelosi's planned use of military aircraft in retaliation for her suggestion that he delay his State of the Union address. A Smithsonian employee, who says she is at risk of losing her apartment, stands alongside other furloughed workers as they bring unpaid bills to Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's office. William Barr, President Trump's pick to be the next Attorney General, listens as senators pepper him with questions on the first day of his Senate confirmation hearings.

The third Women's March returned to Washington on Saturday ‚Äî this time on Day 29 of the longest government shutdown in U.S. history.
üî∏
The original march in 2017, the day after President Donald Trump's inauguration, is generally regarded as the largest protest in the nation‚Äôs capital since the Vietnam era. But this year was a more modest affair. An estimated 100,000 protesters packed several blocks around Freedom Plaza, just east of the White House, holding a daylong rally.
üî∏
The original plan was to gather on the National Mall. But with the forecast calling for snow and freezing rain and the National Park Service no longer plowing snow because of the shutdown, organizers on Thursday changed the march's location and route. Preparations for this year's march were also roiled by an intense ideological debate among the movement's leadership, including accusations of anti-Semitism. Link in bio for the full story. üì∑ M. Scott Mahaskey/POLITICO

President Donald Trump on Saturday proposed an immigration deal to end the government shutdown. But the overture had already been rejected by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other Democrats who said it largely repackaged a proposal that had failed earlier.
üî∏
In an address from the White House, Trump offered to provide temporary protection for some undocumented immigrants along with other measures in exchange for $5.7 billion in funding for his wall along the U.S.-Mexico border.
üî∏
The approach offered little hope for ending the government shutdown, which has entered its fifth week. Democrats insisted they would not negotiate on anything while the government remained partially closed. Yet Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said he would test Democratic unity anyway, announcing plans to put Trump's proposal up for a vote next week. Link in bio for the full story. üì∑ AP Photo

Democrats are rallying behind a ‚ÄúGreen New Deal,‚Äù rookie Democratic Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez‚Äôs radical proposal to decarbonize the American economy.
üî∏
While it sounds like a fresh idea, some are looking back to Barack Obama‚Äôs 2009 climate package that poured $90 billion into clean electricity, renewable fuels, advanced batteries, energy efficiency and a slew of other green initiatives. If you haven‚Äôt heard of it, that‚Äôs because it‚Äôs part of an even larger and more controversial piece of legislation: The $800 billion American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, better known as the stimulus.
üî∏
The short-term goal of the stimulus was to save the economy from a depression, but its long-term push to move the economy toward clean energy was overlooked. Now, Democrats are studying the green stimulus as a potential inspiration for a Green New Deal, as well as a cautionary tale. Link in bio for the full story. üì∑ AP Photo

The longest government shutdown in U.S. history will scar the federal bureaucracy and U.S. economy long after workers return. The feds will struggle to dig out of a backlog of hiring and training that‚Äôs essential to pushing out tax refunds, protecting U.S. borders and guiding air traffic. Government contractors are expected to jack up prices on everything from helicopters to IT support, growing wise to an administration that doesn‚Äôt pay its bills for weeks on end. And the agriculture industry, real estate sector, oil drillers and global investors are all bracing for years of cascading setbacks spurred by the pause in government loans, permitting and deal-making approval. The effects of the shutdown could last months, if not years, said former Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson. Link in bio for more on how the shutdown will inflict lasting damage. üì∏: Getty

Special Counsel Robert Mueller‚Äôs office is denying aspects of a blockbuster BuzzFeed news report that Trump instructed his former personal attorney Michael Cohen to lie to Congress about dealings related to a Trump Tower Moscow project under consideration during the 2016 presidential election. School lunches are the next victims of the government shutdown. Under federal school meal programs, school districts typically get paid back by the federal government for the meals they pay up front to give to eligible children. But if the federal funds don‚Äôt come in, they aren‚Äôt allowed to pull from just any account to make up for coming short. Thousands of new kids nationwide eligible for free or low-cost school meals because their parents have been furloughed by the federal government. Some places like the Prairie Hills school district in Kansas is worried about not being able to feed kids at all. With the U.S. Department of Agriculture shuttered in the dispute over funding for Trump‚Äôs border wall, school districts across the country could be faced with scraping together emergency funds to feed low-income public schoolchildren if the shutdown continues another two months. Link in bio for the full story üì∏: Getty

Politically and culturally, Lynchburg, Tennessee is about as red-state America as you can get. So it might come as a surprise that at Motlow State Community College‚Äôs Moore County campus, every local attends for free. In fact, anyone from Tennessee can go for free, courtesy of the state government. The state‚Äôs free-college program, called Tennessee Promise, has been offering two years of tuition-free community college or technical school to all high school graduates, regardless of income, since 2014. The results here have been so promising that the state‚Äôs conservative Legislature decided to double down, expanding free community college beginning last year to all adults, regardless of income, who don‚Äôt already have a credential. Its success holds lessons for not only how to talk about education in America, but how to bridge political divides by reaching out to those who feel left behind, in rural and urban America alike. Link in bio for more on the red state that loves free college. üì∏: Hollis Bennett for @politicomag

Sen. Lindsey Graham wants the president and speaker to play nice. President Trump has been uncharacteristically silent after Speaker Nancy Pelosi delivered an explosive letter calling for the postponement of the State of the Union address. The partial government shutdown is starting to look like a serious crisis that could nudge the U.S. toward recession‚Äîwith potential impacts for Trump's reelection campaign. There could have been ‚Äúcollusion‚Äù between Trump's presidential campaign and Russian officials, Rudy Giuliani said, but if there was, Trump didn't do it, he added. ‚ÄúI never said there was no collusion between the campaign, or people in the campaign,‚Äù Giuliani, Trump‚Äôs personal attorney, said during an interview with CNN anchor Chris Cuomo. Beto O‚ÄôRourke has left Texas, decamping for a highly anticipated road trip, but his former advisers are quietly sketching the outline of a Bernie Sanders-style campaign model for his potential presidential run. Ted Cruz last year was supported by the creation of hundreds of ‚Äúpop-up‚Äù offices across Texas that served as decentralized hubs for volunteers and get-out-the-vote operations. Four out of 10 students who start college don‚Äôt finish in at least six years‚Äîsome never. But for the past seven years, Georgia State University has monitored its 52,000 students using 800 different academic risk factors, from how well they're doing in algebra to whether they've started to miss class regularly. The goal is to catch students before they reach a crisis point and provide the advising and instructional help to get them through it. (Pictured above is Kiara Collins, an adviser helping a student using the custom software.) Their six-year graduation rate in 2018 was 55 percent, up from 48 percent in 2011 before the program rolled out. That might not sound earth-shattering, but when it comes to college completion, every percentage point counts. Link in bio for more details on the "Moneyball" solution for higher education. üì∏: Raymond McCrea for @politicomag

British politics is broken. It may not be fixable in time to solve the Brexit mess. The U.K. wakes up Wednesday with a government unable to govern ‚Äî in office, but without the numbers to fulfill its central purpose: a negotiated exit from the European Union. The president tweeted 2,843 times in 2018‚Äîthat‚Äôs 616 more tweets than last year. And there were only 16 days when Trump didn‚Äôt tweet at all. We analyzed each and every tweet to take a look back at the president‚Äôs obessesions, moods and often, his television viewing habits, in the last 365 days. We found that Trump spent more time promoting himself or his administration than attacking his enemies in the last year, especially on topics like the economy and U.S.-Mexico relations. On the Russia investigation, however Trump went mostly negative, in 273 of his 310 tweets adressing Mueller‚Äôs probe this year, he was on the attack. Research facilities allowed to grow and test medical marijuana: 1. States that allow medical marijuana: 33 (and 10 of those states have taken steps to decriminalize or legalize pot for recreational use). This gap shows the major disconnect between the federal government‚Äôs oversight of marijuana and the consumer market. And that gap has real world consequences: Legitimate medical research into the impact of cannabis on everything from anxiety to Parkinson‚Äôs disease is not only slowed down ‚Äî scientists don‚Äôt even have a product that matches real-world use.  Americans can legally buy high quality marijuana in most states, but when scientists want to study pot in a lab, they‚Äôre basically stuck with schwag. Link in bio for the full story. üì∏ AP Photo

Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen sought to deflect blame for the Christmas Eve death of an 8-year-old Guatemalan boy in the custody of U.S. Border Patrol agents. Breaking: President Trump has arrived in Iraq to visit U.S. troops there for the first time during his presidency. He had come under criticism for not going earlier, and has been hinting for weeks that he would visit soon. The trip comes days after Trump ordered the 2,000 U.S. troops in Syria to come home, and pushed to cut the 14,000-strong U.S. military contingent in Afghanistan in half. Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg is back at home recovering after being released from the hospital Tuesday following surgery to remove cancerous lung nodules. When Donald Trump‚Äôs social media manager saw his boss's tweet on Feb. 5, 2013, he was perplexed. Justin McConney (right) typically typed and sent Trump‚Äôs tweets, but this time he hadn‚Äôt. "The moment I found out Trump could tweet himself was comparable to the moment in 'Jurassic Park' when Dr. Grant realized that velociraptors could open doors," recalled McConney, who was the Trump Organization‚Äôs director of social media from 2011 to 2017. "I was like, 'Oh no.' " At the time, no one ‚Äî not even McConney himself ‚Äî could grasp what was to come. Now, in rare on-the-record interviews, McConney has told the story of Trump‚Äôs journey from an old-school Luddite to a social media maven. Theresa May won a vote of confidence in her leadership of the Conservative party on Wednesday, with 200 votes in favor and 117 votes against.

Trump has referred to the migrant caravan as nothing more than a ‚Äúlawless‚Äù mob of potentially violent criminals. But the 6,000 asylum seekers have created a proto-democracy, complete with a sophisticated ruling structure with everything from a press shop to a department of public works.

When the migrants needed to make public announcements, debate the best routes and vote on different plans, they established a nightly general assembly as a forum open to all, Athens-style. 
And they‚Äôve elected a nine-person Governance and Dialogue Council to advocate to human rights watch dogs and local government for basic needs like food, shelter and safety. For some migrants, their new democracy might be the first time they‚Äôve trusted a government before‚Äîeven if it‚Äôs one they created essentially overnight. It was supposed to be the ‚ÄúYear of the Woman,‚Äù but dozens of females in the world of politics told us that they weren‚Äôt invited to the party.  We interviewed over 50 women to try to understand how and why they feel shut out of the high profile and often lucrative business of politics. Even with 42 new women elected to the Senate and the House, women described an often futile struggle to be taken seriously by colleagues and candidates alike ‚Äîand even female candidates. ‚ÄúThere is a boys‚Äô club‚Äîregardless of party‚Äîthat tends to take care of each other,‚Äù said Laura Chapin, a political communications consultant, who worked with former Colorado Governor Roy Romer‚Äôs son Chris Romer on his mayoral campaign in Denver. (Chapin is pictured above with Roy Romer.)
Among the women we spoke to were (swipe üëà) Mindy Finn, running mate of U.S. independent presidential candidate Evan McMullin, Republican pollster Kristen Soltis Anderson and EMILY's List president Stephanie Schriock. Link in bio for what they said about the hardest glass ceiling in politics. üì∏ AP Photo and Getty Images

The Trump White House's longest-running personnel drama may finally be over: Chief of staff John Kelly is expected to step down in the coming days, according to two administration officials. Kelly, who joined the White House staff in July 2017, has weathered several months of rumors that the president wants him out. But the officials said this time seemed different, noting that the relationship between the president and his embattled chief of staff has recently bottomed out and that his departure seems imminent. Link in bio for the full story. üì∏ Getty Images

President Trump plans to nominate former Attorney General William Barr to his old job, naming a formal replacement for Jeff Sessions after ousting him last month. He also announced that State Department spokeswoman Heather Nauert (swipe üëâ) will be nominated to serve as United Nations ambassador. Nikki Haley, the current ambassador, will step down at the end of the year.

Barr's nomination inserts a new controversial figure into special counsel Robert Mueller‚Äôs Russia investigation. The White House counsel‚Äôs office has in recent weeks had several conversations with Barr, who initially urged the president‚Äôs advisers to look at other candidates. Barr has not shied away from sharing his opinions about several of the key issues central to the Mueller probe.
In an op-ed in May 2017, he defended Trump‚Äôs move just days earlier to fire FBI Director James Comey. Link in bio for more on Barr.

Today marks 77 years since Japanese fighter pilots launched a surprise attack on the Pearl Harbor naval base in Hawaii, killing more than 2,400 Americans, including both military personnel and civilians. President Franklin D. Roosevelt responded by demanding that Congress allow the United States to declare war the very next day, which it did.

The U.S. was reluctant to join another Europe-based global war, and it had initially pursued economic sanctions to support western friends and counter aggressing trading partners, such as Japan. The attack on Pearl Harbor is widely accepted as the primary reason the U.S. entered WWII.

The American lives lost on that day are remembered each year on Pearl Harbor Remembrance Day, with memorials in the Capitol and the still-active military base in Oahu. üì∑ Getty Images

Ousted FBI Director James Comey returns to Capitol Hill Friday for his first appearance in 18 months. And this time, it'll be out of the camera's glare. With House Republicans eager to try and nail down the ousted FBI director on several issues before they give up their majority, Comey will appear before the House intelligence and judiciary committees for a closed-door hearing. A transcript of his testimony is expected to be released about 24 hours after he appears.

Republican leaders have questioned Comey's honesty about his interactions with Trump and his decision to not recommend criminal charges against Hillary Clinton for her handling of classified information. They also want to press him on a court-approved surveillance warrant for former Trump campaign aide Carter Page. Democrats, meanwhile, have long felt aggrieved at how Republicans have acted in during their FBI investigation. Link in bio for more. üì∏ Getty Images

Sen. Dianne Feinstein doesn't expect California to receive the $9 billion she requested from congressional leaders to help with recovery from the deadliest and most destructive wildfire her state has ever experienced, adding that she doesn‚Äôt have an update on negotiations over a disaster aid package. Feinstein recently penned a letter with Sen. Kamala Harris asking for Congress to deliver on Gov. Jerry Brown‚Äôs request to help California recover from the Camp, Woolsey and Hill fires that simultaneously blazed at each end of the state last month, destroying more than 14,000 homes and killing more than 80 people.

So far, FEMA has approved nearly $36 million in individual assistance for those affected by the California wildfires since President Trump made a major disaster declaration on Nov. 12. That includes almost $25 million in housing assistance and more than $11 million for things like child care expenses for people who have been displaced. As of the agency's latest official tally in November, the Disaster Relief Fund that is used to cover that assistance and broader community rebuilding efforts had a balance of more than $14 billion. Above, a family searches through the ashes of their burned home in Paradise, California, which was ravaged by the Camp wildfire. üì∏ Getty Images

Jeff Sessions hinted that he‚Äôs done with politics. There was speculation that he might mount a bid for his old job as Attorney General, but he says he‚Äôs not missing the Senate and won‚Äôt decide on a run anytime soon.

Senator Doug Jones of Alabama is seen as the most vulnerable incumbent on the ballot in two years and some think Sessions can be a prime candidate to beat him.

After enduring months of attacks from Trump for recusing himself from the Russia probe and for being forced to leave his position after midterms, he says he‚Äôs eager to decompress. He plans to go to Alabama, where he was a former Senator before he makes an official statement.  Sessions was chatty as ever, though, about other areas of the Trump administration. Link in bio for his thoughts on acting attorney general Matt Whitaker and the criminal justice reform effort in the Senate.

In Atlanta, ambitious activist Abiodun Henderson is helping ex-cons learn to become urban farmers.  She started the organization Gangstas to Growers hoping that teaching young people farming skills will break the cycle of incarceration in the city. 
Atlanta has the widest gap between rich and poor in the nation, and in Historic black neighborhoods just west of a the new $1.6 billion Mercedes-Benz stadium, the unemployment rate was much higher than the city‚Äôs average of 4 percent. ‚ÄúI knew farmers who needed labor. I knew folks in the community who needed money. I couldn‚Äôt preach to folks without providing opportunities,‚Äù she told us. Link in bio for more on Gangstas to Growers. üì∏ Mark Peterson/Redux Pictures for @politicomag

Former President George W. Bush shares a hug with his father's former Secretary of State James Baker, right, after Baker gave a eulogy to former President George H.W Bush. ‚ÄúWe rejoice Mr. President that you are safely tucked in now and through the ages with God's loving arms around you. Because our glory, George, was to have you as our president and as such a friend,‚Äù Baker said tearfully.

Rep. Pramila Jayapal is one of the loudest champions of "Medicare for all." And she says that insurers and pharmaceutical companies ‚Äî not Republicans or centrist Democrats ‚Äî are the biggest threat to progressives' ambitious health plan. The industry "has so much profit built into the system that they are going to fight us like hell on this," Jayapal said on our Pulse Check podcast. 
Jayapal stressed that ‚Äî just a month out from the midterm elections ‚Äî it's far too soon to compromise on a vision like Medicare for All. "I'm a realist," she said. "But I also am an optimist ‚Äî and I don't believe that any great social change in this country has ever come by thinking small." Link in bio to listen to her ambitious plans for 2019. üì∏ AP Photo

Most voters worried about climate change, a new poll shows. Two-thirds of voters are very or somewhat concerned about last month's federal climate report that detailed how climate change will impact the U.S. economy. Meanwhile 17% are not too concerned and just 11% aren‚Äôt concerned at all. President Trump described the federal report as ‚Äúfine," but he disputed the report‚Äôs conclusions that climate change could cost the U.S. economy hundreds of billions of dollars per year by the end of the century, telling reporters, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt believe it.‚Äù
üî∏
 The latest POLITICO/Morning Consult poll shows that a majority of voters agrees with the scientific consensus ‚Äî and disagrees with Trump ‚Äî that climate change is being caused by human activity. But 30% say it‚Äôs a natural phenomenon, 4% say climate change is not happening and 8% are undecided. Link in bio for the full poll results.

The Trumps, Obamas, Clintons and Carters sat in the front row together at George H.W. Bush‚Äôs funeral today to say goodbye to the 41st president. Among those who delivered eulogies were former senator Al Simpson, presidential biographer Jon Meacham and George W. Bush.

Bush gave an emotional tribute to his father and spoke about how he lived life to the fullest: driving his boat across the Atlantic at age 85; parachuting out of an aircraft at age 90. ‚ÄúI once heard it said of man that ‚ÄòThe idea is to die young as late as possible,‚Äù Bush said. Link in bio for more from today‚Äôs state funeral ‚Äì the first one since former President Gerald Ford died in 2006.
(üì∑: AP and Getty)

Fighting voter fraud has been a Republican rallying cry for years. But the GOP now finds one of its own candidates, Mark Harris, at the center of the biggest alleged election fraud in recent memory. Roger Stone won‚Äôt stop talking. The longtime political adviser to President Trump gives lengthy interviews about his role in the 2016 presidential election. He writes combative op-eds about Robert Mueller, who is investigating him. He invites reporters into his home for open-ended hangout sessions. It‚Äôs all part of a counterattack against the special counsel‚Äôs Russia investigation, which many legal experts believe is closing in on Stone.

Meanwhile, Stone appears unfazed that his media appearances makes him an open book for Mueller‚Äôs prosecutors as they decide whether the truth of the 2016 campaign makes him a criminal or just a bragger with a big mouth. Even lawyers he‚Äôs consulted with admit it‚Äôs a risky move considering Mueller has held other people‚Äôs public commentary against them in court. Link in bio for the full story‚Äîand how Stone is using the spotlight to raise money to pay his lawyers. üì∏ Getty Images

Breaking: Special counsel Robert Mueller recommended that Michael Flynn receive no prison time for the false statements he made to the FBI. Mueller reasoned in a court filing that Flynn, President Trump‚Äôs former national security adviser, provided ‚Äúsubstantial assistance‚Äù to the ongoing investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 election. ‚ÄúThe defendant deserves credit for accepting responsibility in a timely fashion and substantially assisting the government,‚Äù Mueller wrote.

Flynn participated in 19 interviews with the special counsel and other Justice Department prosecutors. The court filing, however, was heavily redacted and offered little insight into the information Flynn actually provided. Link in bio for the full story. üì∏ AP Photo

Jeb Bush said his father was ‚Äúthe most generous, kind person you‚Äôd ever meet.‚Äù He was the kind of person who didn‚Äôt let poor health stop him from enjoying a martini with former Secretary of State James Baker ‚Äî even in the hospital, even at 10 in the morning.

Joe Biden is fueling more 2020 speculation, claiming that he is "the most qualified person in the country to be president" and teasing that an announcement about his candidacy could come within six weeks.

President Trump is handling former President George H.W. Bush's death with abnormal normality. It's a surprising look for a man who usually shatters sacred political norms. Trump visited Capitol Hill Monday to pay tribute to the 41st president‚Äîand even extended the display of respect to the late president‚Äôs son, George W. Bush, whom Trump has called as ‚Äúthe worst president ever.‚Äù Trump offered Bush the use of his official guest residence while the younger Bush is in Washington for the events surrounding his father‚Äôs funeral, according to a White House official.

The source of Trump‚Äôs unusual restraint is unclear. It may be that he learned the hard way earlier this year what can happen when he fails to show fulsome respect for a deceased political icon. So far, he's avoided the scathing reviews that followed his cool response to the August death of former Sen. John McCain. Link in bio for more on how Trump has traded in jabs at the Bush family for traditional etiquette after the family patriarch's passing. üì∏ Getty Images

Nancy Pelosi hugs George W. Bush at a ceremony in the Capitol for his late father.

California‚Äôs Gov.-elect Gavin Newsom signaled that he‚Äôs not interested in keeping National Guard troops at the U.S.-Mexican border. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the point in our National Guard being there at this point? I can‚Äôt see any,‚Äù the California Gov.-elect told us in an exclusive interview on Friday.

Newsom intends to seek more state resources, like exploring a role for California‚Äôs Office of Emergency Services, to aid refugees who have already arrived in California. A meeting between President Trump and top Democratic leaders Sen. Chuck Schumer and Rep. Nancy Pelosi scheduled for Tuesday was canceled due to the death of former President George H.W. Bush, according to a Democratic aide. The canceled meeting pushes back crucial talks just days before a potential government shutdown. Congress has until Friday to act before funding for large swaths of the federal government runs out.

While Trump has expressed a willingness to pass a short-term funding extension, weekend talks between the two parties over a spending stopgap failed to lead to an agreement. GOP and Democratic leaders couldn't agree on a one- or two-week funding deal. Democrats were pushing for a one-week extension, while Republicans wanted two weeks. Link in bio for the full story. üì∏ AP Photo

President Trump has publicly endorsed the bipartisan prison and sentencing reform bill that's currently stalled in the Senate, but he hasn‚Äôt called out Majority Leader Mitch McConnell for holding up the legislation. He‚Äôs called McConnell privately and urged him to take up the bill but hasn‚Äôt unleashed his most aggressive tactics. Trump's lack of action makes it seem he's reluctant to spend political capital on the issue ‚Äî and raises doubts among bill supporters and opponents about how invested in criminal justice reform the president really is.

Trump took up the cause of criminal justice reform last month at the urging of his son-in-law, Jared Kushner, but the president‚Äôs endorsement was as much an effort to distract from Republican losses in the midterm elections as a reflection of his heartfelt convictions, according to two sources familiar with his thinking. Trump had even previously said that some of the drug offenders toward whom the bill would show leniency should receive the death penalty. Link in bio for the full story. üì∏ AP Photo

Pittsburgh's Tree of Life Synagogue set up its menorah in preparation for the first night of Hanukkah on Sunday. The menorah sits behind a memorial for the 11 people shot and killed at the synagogue in October. üì∏ AP Photo

President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping have reached a ceasefire in their trade war.
üî∏
Trump has agreed not to raise tariffs further while negotiations continue, the White House said in a statement. China will agree to purchase more U.S. agricultural, energy and other products.
üî∏
The move means that U.S. tariffs on $200 billion worth of goods will not rise to 25 percent on Jan. 1, from 10 percent currently, as Trump had previously threatened.

The two leaders met for dinner Saturday evening in Buenos Aires on the sidelines of the annual G-20 leaders summit.
üî∏
Their agreement follows months of escalating trade friction as the U.S. complained about Beijing's intellectual property practices. Link in bio for the full story. üì∑ AP Photo

George H.W. Bush has died at age 94. The 41st president navigated the U.S. through the end of the Cold War and a realignment of American relations with the Middle East. Link in bio for the full obit.

Did you know that Elizabeth Warren was once a registered Republican? She was an independent and then a Republican until 1996. But the more Republicans seemed to side with Wall Street, the less Republican she felt, she said. So she registered as a Democrat.

Back then, Warren was a respected but little-known academic with an obscure specialty. But then Dr. Phil called ‚Äì and he opened a door for her to become a national political figure.

Jeff Flake is finally taking a stand on the need to protect Robert Mueller ‚Äì and it‚Äôs infuriating his fellow Republicans. Trump is going for a full-blown Space Force. The president plans to ask Congress to establish a Space Force as an independent branch of the military ‚Äî committing to the biggest restructuring of the U.S. military in seven decades, according to a draft memo that we obtained.

The memo is still awaiting final review, but it shows that Trump is still interested in pursuing the entirely new Space Force branch, despite bipartisan skepticism on the Hill and even initial opposition within the Pentagon.

Trump also intends to carry out plans already underway to establish a U.S Space Command. It would absorb all space-related responsibilities carried out by the U.S. Strategic Command and would train space forces from all military branches until the Space Force is established. Link in bio for the full story.

Trump‚Äôs trade war is driving production out of China ‚Äî but not to America. Companies like Manwah, a furniture company, are now moving to Vietnam and other countries where Trump‚Äôs tariffs won‚Äôt apply. To many of them, this seems like the only practical solution to avoid getting hit by the 10% tariffs on $200 billion worth of Chinese imports.

In the U.S., companies are trying to decide what they‚Äôll do if those tariffs increase to 25%. One manager at a Virginia family business told us they‚Äôre considering three options: 1) Keep buying Chinese-made furniture and pass the extra costs on to the customer, which will probably result in lost sales; 2) Buy more product from Southeast Asian countries, where capacity or quality isn‚Äôt guaranteed; or 3) Buy more American-made products, which might be too expensive for their core customers.

Link in bio for more on how U.S. and Chinese companies are navigating Trump‚Äôs trade war. (üì∑: He Huifeng/South China Morning Post)

A new poll found that ‚Öì of Europeans surveyed had little to no knowledge of the Holocaust.
üî∏
In the early 20th century, Adolf Hitler, then-chancellor of Germany, emphasized Aryan racial purity in his manifesto. His Nazi Party's leadership indoctrinated schools and social life with anti-Semitic propaganda throughout the 1930s, primarily demonizing Jewish people, as well as LGBT, Africans, Romani and people with disabilities.

The party's "Final Solution of the Jewish Question," also known as the Holocaust, resulted in millions of Jewish people being deported and placed in ghettos or camps to be exterminated en masse in the 1940s.
üî∏
According to that same poll, about ‚Öì of Europeans believe Jewish people use the Holocaust to advance their own positions or goals, with more than a quarter of Europeans saying Jewish people have too much influence in business and finance.
üî∏
French Prime Minister Edouard Philippe said earlier this month that anti-Semitism is on the rise in his country, with a jump in incidents in the first nine months of 2018. He said his French government is workshopping ways to tackle anti-Semitism in schools.
üî∏
The chief executive of the U.K. Holocaust Educational Trust said the poll showed a "disappointing lack of knowledge about the Holocaust" and confirmed a "worrying increase" in the number of people who hold anti-Semitic views. Link to the full story in our bio. (üì∑ Getty)

Housing is becoming less and less affordable, even for the middle class. Ready for a mini Thanksgiving history lesson? Starting tomorrow, President Donald Trump is penciling in lengthy holiday visits to Mar-a-Lago, spending much of the year‚Äôs end ‚Äî and some of January ‚Äî outside of the White House.

Trump‚Äôs trips to his Palm Beach resort and his golf club in Bedminster, New Jersey have often become opportunities for him to vent frustrations to his allies, and to get his friends‚Äô opinions about key staffers.

White House aides and outside advisers acknowledge privately that Trump is often more impulsive when he‚Äôs on the road and out of sight of senior staffers. And his upcoming on-the-road time comes as he weighs a shakeup of his administration.

A White House official said it remained unclear what Trump would decide when it comes to personnel shifts, but added that there have been frequent conversations in the West Wing in recent weeks about who is coming and going.

In Florida, the recounts are finally over, and Republicans officially won both the Senate and governor's races. But there's still one controversy left: Did a bad ballot design cost Democrats the Senate race?
üî∏
Everyone's looking at Broward County, where the undervote rate in the Senate race was much bigger than in any other Florida county. On the ballot here, the Senate race was tucked below the instructions in the lower left-hand corner. It's possible that thousands of people didn't vote in the Senate race because they probably didn‚Äôt see it on the ballot. And if you assume that the Senate race would have gotten as many total votes as the governor's race, and that the county would vote like other demographically/geographically/politically similar counties, then Democrat Bill Nelson would have won an extra 9,746 votes. That would have dropped Republican Rick Scott's statewide lead of 10,033 to just 287 votes. (Still a win for Scott, though.)
üî∏
It's hard to say whether Broward County's bad ballot killed Nelson‚Äôs political career. But either way, it wasn't looking good for the county's election supervisor, Brenda Snipes (pictured here). Instead of facing an embarrassing removal from office, she announced her resignation on Sunday. Democrat Stacey Abrams announced Friday that Brian Kemp, her Republican opponent in the Georgia gubernatorial race, would be certified as governor. "I acknowledge that former Secretary of State Brian Kemp will be certified as the victor in the 2018 gubernatorial election," Abrams said at a press conference Friday, effectively conceding that she lost the race.

But Abrams refused to concede, arguing that there were outstanding votes that needed to be counted. Refugees have been getting a lot of attention from the current administration, most of it negative. And it doesn‚Äôt take a dime from the government. It takes the average American refugee seven years to become self-supporting, according to a Stockton University study. Breaking: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos' newly revealed guidelines for how schools should handle sexual misconduct allegations gives more protection to the accused‚Äîa move almost certain to ignite a firestorm.  DeVos said the plan is aimed at boosting due process for the accused, but advocates warn it will create more barriers for students seeking justice.

The proposal includes a narrower definition of sexual harassment than in the past ‚Äî as unwanted conduct that is "severe, pervasive, and objectively offensive" ‚Äî and it would give both K-12 schools and colleges more latitude in how they handle allegations. ‚ÄúThis rule will return schools back to a time where rape, assault and harassment were swept under the rug," said Jess Davidson, executive director of End Rape on Campus. Meanwhile, men's rights advocates and civil liberties groups have cheered the administration's efforts, arguing the Obama-era policies they are replacing led schools to trample the due process rights of the accused. Link in bio for more details of the plan. üì∏ Getty Images

We visited Wisconsin to talk to voters over 50 about the issues that were most important to them this election cycle‚Äîand a lot of it came back to health care. President Trump made an unexpected announcement on Tuesday: Neomi Rao, an administrator with the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs, will replace Justice Brett Kavanaugh on the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals. The announcement came as a surprise to the attendees of a Diya lighting ceremony in the White House commemorating Diwali, the festival of lights celebrated by millions of Indians and Southeast Asians around the world. Rao's current position makes her a powerful Trump ally at the center of one of his core campaign promises: cutting excessive regulations from the federal government.

If confirmed by the Senate, Rao, who is 44, would be able to serve a lifetime post on the D.C. court, largely considered the second highest court in the nation, and a training ground for future Supreme Court justices. Rao was also a student of Justice Clarence Thomas. She has spoken at multiple events at the Federalist Society, the conservative legal scholarship group that has influenced Trump's judicial picks, including Kavanaugh and Justice Neil Gorsuch. üì∏ @smahaskey

Ojeda's concession speech sounded more like a counterattack against the president. ‚ÄúYou called me a stone-cold crazy wacko and then you mispronounced the way I say my name! I‚Äôm Richard Ojeda, and I‚Äôm not done fighting, and neither are we!‚Äù Ojeda lost his race last week by 12 points, but was emboldened by a 31-point shift toward blue since Trump won the district by a 49-point margin in 2016. Half of voters say the new Democratic-controlled House should not move forward with impeaching Donald Trump next year.

This puts House Democrats in a tough position with their base because 61 percent of Democratic voters want Congress to start with impeaching the president next year.

Support for impeachment is lacking among Republicans (8%) and independents (29%). And the fact that Republicans still have control of the Senate ‚Äî which has the final say on removing the president after a formal impeachment ‚Äî also means any impeachment effort likely won‚Äôt result in Trump‚Äôs removal before the 2020 elections.

The POLITICO/Morning Consult poll also showed that roughly 49 percent of voters describe themselves as ‚Äúexcited‚Äù or ‚Äúsatisfied‚Äù that Democrats won the House majority ‚Äî more than the 40 percent who say they are ‚Äúangry‚Äù or ‚Äúdissatisfied.‚Äù But voters render a split decision on continued GOP control of the Senate: 44 percent say they are ‚Äúexcited‚Äù or ‚Äúsatisfied,‚Äù and the same percentage are ‚Äúangry‚Äù or ‚Äúdissatisfied.‚Äù Link in our bio for more stats from our poll. ‚òùÔ∏è

As Florida deals with the aftermath of the chaotic 2018 elections, insiders say Broward County Elections Supervisor Brenda Snipes' days in office are numbered. Suspending Snipes from office would put a final exclamation point on one of the most contested midterms in recent Florida history, which has resulted in three statewide recounts as well as recounts in three local legislative races. ‚ÄúThis is not just the most troubled elections office in the state, it‚Äôs the most troubled elections office in the nation,‚Äù said Sen. Marco Rubio, who contends that Snipes needs to be removed from office once the recounts that began Sunday in the races for governor and U.S. Senate are over. As Mueller's boss, Whitaker will have control over the special counsel‚Äôs budget, as well as his decisions on subpoenas, indictments and the public disclosure of a final report describing his findings about Russian meddling in the 2016 election, any possible coordination between the Kremlin and the Trump campaign and Trump's potential attempts to obstruct justice. Florida solidified its status as Trump Country this week, reinvigorating Republicans and dispiriting Democrats in America‚Äôs largest swing state.
üî∏
After Trump's victory here in 2016, Democrats thought they would get even this year. Florida was supposed to be washed with a blue wave this time. Voters were supposed to do what they normally do: punish the party of the president in power during his first midterm. But that didn‚Äôt happen.
üî∏
The Democratic party‚Äôs fresh new face, Andrew Gillum, lost to Trump-backed Ron DeSantis. And the Senate race between Democratic incumbent Sen. Bill Nelson and Trump-backed Gov. Rick Scott is so close it‚Äôs headed to a recount. The race for state agriculture commissioner will also go to a recount, as will a state Senate race and two state House races.
üî∏
‚ÄúI'm calling this right now: Unless Trump is getting taken down easily in his re-election, he is winning Florida in 2020. It's not a tossup. It's Lean-R,‚Äù said Matt Isbell, a Democratic data analyst based in Florida. ‚ÄúThe Florida election map is changing under Trump. It‚Äôs the data.‚Äù üì∏ Getty Images

Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg fractured three ribs after suffering a fall Wednesday night in her office and has been admitted to the hospital, according to the court. The court said Thursday morning that Ginsburg went home after the fall, and after experiencing discomfort overnight, she went to George Washington University Hospital, where tests showed she fractured three ribs on her left side. She was admitted for "observation and treatment."
üî∏
Ginsburg, 85, is the oldest justice on the court. It's unclear how long Ginsburg will stay in the hospital, but she will miss the investiture ceremony for Justice Brett Kavanaugh, where Chief Justice John Roberts will administer the Judicial Oath to him. üì∏

Rep. Hakeem Jeffries is launching a bid to become House Democratic Caucus chair. It's a move some of his supporters hope would position him to one day become the first black speaker should he win. Multiple critics of Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi have been trying to get the Democrat from Brooklyn to challenge her for the job, but Jeffries' declaration for the No. 4 position leaves Pelosi critics without a leader they believe they can win with. The group has been trying to find someone willing to challenge Pelosi, but so far they‚Äôve been unsuccessful. Jeffries, while only 48 and just elected to his fourth term, is well liked in the Democratic Caucus and is seen as a rising star.
üî∏
Jeffries' move is sure to shake up the caucus chair race. Current Vice Caucus Chair Linda S√°nchez is also trying to move up the ladder to claim the position. And Rep. Barbara Lee, another Congressional Black Caucus member, has also been whipping for the post, sending care packages of candy to offices in her bid to woo lawmakers and candidates. Link in bio for more. üì∏ AP Photo

Beto O'Rourke's loss means he's now set up to run full time for president in 2020 ‚Äì and immediately become a top Democratic candidate.
üî∏
He hasn't officially said anything about running in 2020 yet, but in the last few months he's built up a national brand and fundraising base that few other Democrats can match. His progressive positions might not have worked in Texas, but they only make him a stronger national candidate for a Democratic Party that has been moving left. And he has already captivated Democrats in key places like Iowa (the first-in-the-nation primary state) and New Hampshire (the second state on the presidential nominating calendar).
üî∏
The results of O'Rourke's tight race against Ted Cruz ‚Äì 48.3% to 50.9% ‚Äì showed that an unapologetic liberal can compete and almost win in Texas. Link in bio to read about how O'Rourke actually dodged a bullet this week.
üì∑: Getty

Jeff Sessions is out as attorney general, President Trump announced on wednesday. Sessions resigned at the president‚Äôs request. His chief of staff, Matthew Whitaker, will take over as the acting head of the Justice Department. Trump said a permanent replacement would be nominated ‚Äúat a later date.‚Äù
üî∏
With the change atop DOJ, Deputy AG Rod Rosenstein will no longer oversee special counsel Robert Mueller‚Äôs probe into the Trump 2016 campaign and Russian hackers.
üî∏
Rosenstein was only overseeing the probe because Sessions had recused himself from any involvement with the special counsel, and a DOJ spokesperson indicated Wednesday that Whitaker would take over "all matters under the purview of the Department of Justice," including the Mueller probe. Link in bio for more. üì∏Getty Images

The two GOP lawmakers under federal indictment both won re-election: New York's Chris Collins and California's Duncan Hunter. They‚Äôre both supporters of President Trump.
üî∏
Collins was indicted on insider-trading charges this summer, and Hunter was indicted in August on charges of using his campaign account as a personal slush fund (he pleaded not guilty and denies the allegations). üì∏ Getty Images

The Florida Senate race is headed for a recount. Democrat Sen. Bill Nelson‚Äôs campaign announced the news Wednesday morning. 
Of the 8.1 million votes cast, Republican Gov. Rick Scott (swipe üëà) leads by just 34,537 votes, which is less than one-half point, the threshold for a state-mandated recount. Now, all of Florida's 67 counties need to recheck tally totals. The deadline for the process is noon on Nov. 10. üì∏ Getty Images

For President Trump, 2020 "begins today," said Brian Walsh, President of the pro-Trump America First Action super PAC. Trump had one of his 2016 campaign managers, Corey Lewandowski, and the man who will run his 2020 re-election bid, Brad Parscale, by his side as he watched Tuesday night‚Äôs mixed election returns. Although the White House billed the event as a midterm watch party, the presence of Lewandowski and Parscale underscored that it may have more accurately been described as the unofficial kickoff of Trump‚Äôs 2020 campaign.
üî∏
With the midterms behind him, Trump now dives into a re-election campaign facing a Democratic House, political gridlock ‚Äî and special counsel Robert Mueller's Russia probe. With divided government making further legislative accomplishments almost impossible, Trump will likely leverage the full power of the White House behind his own political survival. And while Tuesday‚Äôs results may have been bruising, in historical terms they are far from a re-election death sentence: Both Presidents Bill Clinton and Barack Obama rebounded from even worse midterm results in their first terms to be comfortably re-elected two years later. Link in bio for more. üì∏ Getty Images

Democrat Joe Manchin won an impressive victory in West Virginia, keeping his seat in a state that Trump easily carried in 2016.
üî∏
He was the only Senate Democrat to vote ‚Äòyes‚Äô on Brett Kavanaugh‚Äôs confirmation, and it seems to have paid off. He relied on his strong personal brand ‚Äî taking a two-day, 700-mile, get-out-the-vote motorcycle ride around the state.
üî∏
Manchin has walked a fine line between President Trump and his own party. He‚Äôs also gone against his party on issues like coal and energy regulation.
üî∏
Manchin‚Äôs Republican opponent, Patrick Morrisey, tried to tie him to national Democrats, slamming his support for Hillary Clinton in 2016. Link in bio on how the most endangered Democrat in America survived. üì∑: Getty

It's official: The next Congress will have a record-breaking number of women. The legislature just surpassed its previous record of 107 women or 20% female representation. One of the winning women was Democrat Abby Finkenauer, who defeated Rep. Rod Blum in Iowa. (She and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez became the first women in their 20s to be elected to Congress‚Äîthey're both 29 years old.)
üî∏
While races are still being called, 103 women have won election or reelection across the country so far. They join 10 women in the Senate who weren‚Äôt up for reelection this year. Link in bio for more on the record-breaking number of women elected to Congress. üì∏ AP Photo

Missouri Republican Josh Hawley flipped one of the nation's most important Senate races to the GOP.  The state Attorney General unseated Sen. Claire McCaskill, who had been one of the GOP's top targets.
üî∏
Hawley, a 38-year-old considered a rising star within the GOP, just won his first elected office two years ago. He tied himself closely to the White House in an effort to make the race a referendum on Trump, who remains popular in Missouri. And Hawley cast McCaskill as out of touch and too liberal for a state that's trended increasingly conservative, citing Trump‚Äôs Supreme Court nominees and the GOP tax law, among other votes.
üî∏
Hawley had 53 percent of the vote to McCaskill‚Äôs 44 percent with 83 percent of precincts reporting when McCaskill conceded the race. ‚ÄúI will be out there fighting with you, I am not going away,‚Äù she said in her remarks. üì∏ AP Photo

Republican Ron DeSantis has defeated Democrat Andrew Gillum in the race for Florida's governorship after one of the most bitter, hard-fought races of the year. President Trump campaigned for DeSantis, holding a rally for him in the state, as Obama-endorsed Gillum sought to become the state's first black governor.
üî∏
Whether measured by rhetoric, tactics or strategy, the campaign between DeSantis and Gillum was shot through with racial politics, putting the nation‚Äôs rawest and most sensitive issue at the center of the competition. Link in bio for more on gubernatorial races across the country.

We are now projecting Democrats will control the House in the new Congress. The Republican-held suburbs where President Trump has proven toxic were crucial to Democrats. From Florida to Texas to Illinois, Republican incumbents who survived reelection in 2016 even as Trump lost their districts fell decisively to Democratic challengers who linked them to the president. After tonight, Democrats will turn to leadership elections where Rep. Nancy Pelosi will seek the 218 votes she needs to become speaker.
üî∏
The first flip of the night came in Northern Virginia, where Democrat Jennifer Wexton, a state senator, beat Republican Rep. Barbara Comstock ‚Äî who won reelection in 2016 even as Trump lost badly in the district. The same trend saw Florida Rep. Carlos Curbelo, Illinois Rep. Peter Roskam, Minnesota Rep. Erik Paulsen, Kansas Rep. Kevin Yoder and Colorado Rep. Mike Coffman all lose in districts that Clinton carried after surviving 2016 challenges.  Link in bio for the latest on the House. üì∏ Getty Images

Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez is now the youngest woman to be elected to U.S. Congress. She is 29 years old. üî∏
Democrats have won back control of the House of Representatives, slicing through Republican-held suburbs where President Trump has proven toxic. Link in bio for more House elections results. üì∏ Getty Images

The first two Muslim women have been elected to Congress. Democrat Rashida Tlaib defeated Sam Johnson in Michigan‚Äôs 13th District. In Minnesota, Ilhan Omar (swipe üëà) defeated Republican Jennifer Zielinksi. üì∏ AP Photo  and Getty Images

Ted Cruz has defeated Democrat Beto O'Rourke in the nationally-watched Texas Senate race. Cruz will now get a second term in Texas, beating back Democrats' aggressive push to flip the biggest red state. Link in bio for more.

Indiana Republican Mike Braun defeated Democratic Sen. Joe Donnelly, flipping a key Senate seat for the GOP. The Republican victory in a race we rated as a toss-up could dampen Democrats' hopes of winning the majority in the upper chamber. Braun had 54 percent of the vote to Donnelly‚Äôs 42 percent when three networks called the race with about half of all precincts reporting.
üî∏
President Donald Trump carried Indiana by nearly 20 percentage points in 2016, underlining Donnelly‚Äôs status as a top target for Republicans in this year‚Äôs midterm elections. The first-term Democrat ran as an avowed centrist, touting his willingness to work with Trump and running ads late in the cycle decrying the ‚Äúradical left.‚Äù Link in bio for more Senate results. üì∏ AP Photo

Democrat Jennifer Wexton just flipped the first House seat of the night. Wexton defeated Republican Rep. Barbara Comstock in Virginia's 10th Congressional district.  With 83.1% of precincts, the Democratic winner had 54.4% of the vote.
üî∏
Comstock had won reelection in 2016 even as President Trump lost badly in the district. Link in bio for more House results.

An Election Day storm is dumping rain on Florida's state capital as race results start to trickle in. The governor's race between Democrat Andrew Gillum and Republican Ron DeSantis was neck-and-neck in the final polls. Above, a member of the media cuts a hole in the ceiling of the press tent at Gillum's election night watch party, before they evacuate, as other members of the press stand outside in the pouring rain (swipe üëà).
üî∏
In another statewide competition in Florida, the toss-up Senate race between Sen. Bill Nelson and Republican challenger Gov. Rick Scott could set records as the most expensive Senate election of all time. Elsewhere in Florida, we're watching for a probable Democratic pickup for Donna Shalala in the 27th District, and a toss-up between Republican Rep. Carlos Curbelo and Democrat Debbie Mucarsel-Powell in FL-26. Link in bio for election results in Florida. üì∏ Getty Images

Tonight could be historic. There‚Äôs a flood of women, minorities and first-time candidates running for office this year, which means Congress could become much more diverse after Election Day. Right now women make up only about a fifth of Congress, which is still mostly white and mostly male.
üî∏
Former state legislator Young Kim is fighting to become the first Korean American woman in Congress if she can hold a tough open seat for the GOP in California‚Äôs 39th District. We rate this race as a toss-up between Kim and her opponent, Democrat Gil Cisneros. The district has gone Republican the last three elections, but in 2016 it voted for Hillary Clinton for president. Link in bio for a list of more potentially history-making races happening Tuesday. üì∏ AP Photo

For thousands of American families, the shocking results of Election Day two years ago collided with another momentous event: the birth of a baby. What has it meant to raise a child in Trump‚Äôs America? Here are the stories of Election Day babies and their families.
üî∏
The first time Jimmy Erickson voted in a presidential election, it was to cast his ballot for Trump. And he did so while his wife Marisa Erickson was five centimeters dilated, laboring to deliver their first child. Jimmy returned in time to help deliver their daughter, Ryleigh, whom they call their ‚Äúrainbow‚Äù baby after having previously suffered three miscarriages. Jimmy, an airline mechanic, mostly continues to support Trump today, but he disapproves of the president‚Äôs decision to exit the Paris climate accord because he worries how global warming will impact his daughter‚Äôs life in the years to come.
üî∏
The first thing Mary Anne Alesci and her husband Joe (swipe üëà) did when she was discharged from the hospital on November 8, 2016‚Äîhaving given birth to their first child three days earlier via emergency C-section‚Äîwas vote. Mary Anne cast her ballot for Clinton, and Joe wrote in Sanders. They went to the voting booth before even going home. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt plan on my son being someone on the sidelines,‚Äù Joe, says of his son TJ. Indeed, the Alescis took TJ to the 2017 March for Science and the 2018 March for Our Lives in Manhattan. TJ‚Äôs sign read: ‚ÄúChange gun reform and then change my diaper.‚Äù Link in bio for more stories from families who welcomed a new child into their lives on November 8, 2016. üì∏ @smahaskey/POLITICO

Election Day is finally here. Before polls even opened this morning, a staggering 36 million voters already cast their ballots, setting the stage for much-higher-than-usual turnout for a midterm. That could potentially mean big surprises on Tuesday night.
üî∏
Voters are going to the polls far faster than in 2014, when 27.2 million people voted early, according to Michael McDonald, a University of Florida professor who tracks voter turnout. And the trend is expected to extend into Election Day. Early voters in three states ‚Äî Texas, Nevada and Arizona ‚Äî have already surpassed total turnout in the last midterm election, data shows, and more states will blow past their normal non-presidential turnout with just a handful more votes on Election Day. The high voting rates could mean results that diverge from any pre-election polls that did not anticipate this year‚Äôs unusually high enthusiasm.
üî∏
‚ÄúThis is not a normal election,‚Äù McDonald said. Link in bio for more. üì∏ AP Photo

Republicans are cutting into Democrats‚Äô lead on the generic congressional ballot, according to a new poll.
üî∏
43% of registered voters would vote for the Democratic congressional candidate in their district ‚Äì just slightly more than the 40% who would vote for a Republican, according to the final POLITICO/Morning Consult poll before Election Day. 18% of registered voters were undecided.
üî∏
Among those who say they are very likely to vote or have already voted, Democrats lead by 4 percentage points ‚Äî 47% to 43%. That‚Äôs a slightly smaller edge for Democrats than other public polls conducted in the immediate run-up to the election, but it fits an overall trend of modest tightening on the general ballot. Link in bio to the full story for more stats.

Republicans would have to sweep virtually all of the 22 toss-up elections to hold on to their House majority.
üî∏
Democrats have pulled ahead in nearly enough races to claim a majority of the 435 seats up for grabs in the first national election of Donald Trump‚Äôs presidency. Our final race ratings show 216 seats in the Democratic column ‚Äî those are either solidly Democratic, likely Democratic or leaning Democratic.
üî∏
The most likely gain for Democrats is between 25 and 40 seats, and they need to pick up just 23 seats to win a majority Tuesday.
üî∏
A Democratic-controlled House ‚Äî nearly unthinkable earlier this decade, given the GOP‚Äôs structural advantages in the way the districts are drawn ‚Äî would represent a rebuke to Trump, even with a booming economy, and grind much of his legislative agenda to a halt until the 2020 election. Link to the full story in our bio. (üì∑ Getty)

Heads up: that Georgia governor‚Äôs race could head into four weeks of overtime. That‚Äôs what‚Äôll happen if neither Democrat Stacey Abrams nor Republican Brian Kemp are able to win more than 50% of the vote in Tuesday‚Äôs election. They would have to go to a runoff on Dec. 4. üî∏
Link in bio for our hour-by-hour guide on how to watch election night results like a pro. üì∑: Getty

Women seem to be fired up about the midterms this year. 68% of them said they're "very motivated" to vote, according to a recent poll. So will there really be a female wave? If the answer‚Äôs yes, it could tip control of the House. 
We asked women who are voting in tomorrow's midterm election what issues are driving them to the polls ‚Äì head to our Story to see what they said. üì∏ AP Photo

House Speaker Paul Ryan called President Trump on Sunday with one final plea on behalf of anxious Republicans: Please, please talk up the booming economy in the final hours before Election Day. Trump, however, had another issue on his mind. He told Ryan that his focus on immigration has fired up the base, according to a source familiar with the call. But two days out from an expected Democratic takeover of the House, Republicans are seriously worried that Trump‚Äôs obsession with all things immigration will exacerbate their losses.
üî∏
Many of these same Republicans welcomed Trump‚Äôs initial talk about the migrant caravan and border security two weeks ago, hoping it would gin up the GOP base in some at-risk, Republican-held districts. But they now fear Trump went overboard ‚Äî and that it could cost them dearly in key suburban districts, from Illinois to Texas. ‚ÄúTrump has hijacked the election,‚Äù said one senior House Republican aide of Trump's focus on immigration. Link in bio for the full story. üì∏ AP Photo

Republicans have painted Rep. Kyrsten Sinema as a liberal in centrist‚Äôs clothing. But the hits against the Democratic candidate in Arizona's highly contested Senate race don't seem to be sticking.
üî∏
Polls either show the race is tied or Sinema with a narrow lead in the historically red state. Strong early vote totals have her supporters hopeful that she will be the first Democrat elected statewide since former Gov. Janet Napolitano was reelected to a second term in 2006.
üî∏
If Sinema wins, her key will have been a relentless focus on health care and education. Health care is a weak point for her opponent, GOP Rep. Martha McSally (swipe üëà). The two-term Republican congresswoman has tried to downplay her vote for the Obamacare repeal bill that would have stripped the health care law‚Äôs popular protections for those with preexisting conditions.
üî∏
But if McSally can keep the Senate seat red in an otherwise rocky year for her party, it‚Äôll be because of the robust Trump-era economy that she‚Äòs been talking up on the campaign trail ‚Äî and her steely presence as the nation‚Äôs first female fighter pilot to fly in combat.
üî∏
Arizonans will decide on Tuesday whether McSally‚Äôs alignment with the president is more in step with the state than Sinema‚Äôs sales pitch as a label-resistant coalition-builder. Link in bio for the full story. üì∑ @smahaskey/POLITICO

Trump is nearing the end of a 11-day rally sprint ahead of Tuesday‚Äôs midterm elections. By Election Day, the president will have headlined 53 MAGA rallies across 23 states, as well as 70 fundraising events since he took office in 2017. He has staged 30 rallies since Labor Day.
üî∏
The busy campaign schedule is striking for a 72-year-old man who doesn‚Äôt believe in exercise, and whose diet has long relied heavily on well-done steaks, McDonald‚Äôs quarter pounders and Diet Coke. ‚ÄúThere are grueling days,‚Äù one White House official said. ‚ÄúI am on the helicopter, I can barely keep my eyes open and he is like, ‚ÄòWhy don‚Äôt we do two more stops?‚Äô‚Äù
üî∏
But Trump‚Äôs packed schedule isn‚Äôt just about boosting Republican candidates ‚Äî it‚Äôs also about competition with the men who have held his office before him, and part of a pass-the-blame strategy if Democrats make big gains on Election Day. Link in bio for the full story. üì∑ AP Photo

Former President Barack Obama campaigned with Stacey Abrams, the Democratic candidate for governor in Georgia, on Friday night. Obama called Abrams the "most experienced, most qualified candidate in this race." The former president made the remarks in front of a packed audience at Morehouse College ‚Äì  just days before the midterms and what‚Äôs expected to be a close gubernatorial race. üì∑: AP Photo

The Nigerian Army seized on Donald Trump's words to justify shooting at protesters in the capital city of Abuja this week.
üî∏
On Thursday, Trump gave what was believed to be a policy announcement for addressing the Central American caravan making its way to the U.S. southern border. He said that if migrants threw rocks at the U.S. military guarding the border, officers should "consider it a rifle."
üî∏
In Nigeria, the Army's official account posted a video of Trump's comments on Twitter with the caption, "Please Watch and Make your Deductions."
üî∏
"We released that video to say if President Trump can say that rocks are as good as a rifle,‚Äù a spokesman for the Nigerian Army told The New York Times. ‚ÄúWhat are they then saying? What did David use to kill Goliath? So a stone is a weapon."
üî∏
Trump then eased off his statement on Friday, but his words had already reverberated across the globe. An watchdog investigation concluded that the military had used automatic weapons in dispersing the assembly, shooting at about 1,000 people as they fled. Link to the full story in our bio. (Photo/Getty)

The Arizona senate race between Republican Martha McSally (left) and Democrat Kyrsten Sinema is neck-and-neck. And just as immigration is taking over the national conversation, the same is happening in Arizona where the topic has already been at the top of voters‚Äô minds for years.
üî∏
Sinema is fighting to become the first Democrat to represent the state in the Senate in more than two decades, and to do that she‚Äôs become one of the most conservative Democrats in Congress‚Äî a new development for her since she used to fall on the far-left side of the spectrum. Meanwhile, McSally is siding with Trump on almost every issue‚Äîincluding immigration. üì∏ AP Photo

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi is launching a charm offensive. She‚Äôs quietly courting Democratic candidates who threaten to block her path back to power‚Äînudging her donors toward candidates, and appearing at private fundraisers for House hopefuls who can't be seen with her publicly. While it‚Äôs too early to say whether she would have the 218 votes to claim the speaker's gavel should her party claim House majority, Pelosi has clearly made inroads.
üî∏
Of the 43 Democratic candidates in districts that we're rating ‚Äúlean-Democrat,‚Äù ‚Äúlikely-Democrat‚Äù or ‚Äútoss-up‚Äù ‚Äî the collection of GOP-held seats most likely to flip ‚Äî only 11 have said they would not back Pelosi for speaker. Of those 11, only four would confirm that they would vote against Pelosi on the House floor next year. While much of the narrative surrounding candidates and Pelosi over the past year has focused on dozens of hopefuls who have called for her to step aside, a closer look at of those most likely to win on Nov. 6 reveals that the number of anti-Pelosi absolutists is relatively small. üì∏ AP Photo

Farmers are losing money thanks to Trump ‚Äî but they still support him. There‚Äôs a disconnect between the negative effect of Trump‚Äôs policies on his voters in farm country and their unwavering support for him. That could limit the size of the Democratic majority widely expected to take control of the House next year and give Trump cover to prolong his aggressive moves against U.S. trading partners.
üî∏
Though soybean prices have plunged 20 percent and farm incomes are down 50 percent over the past five years, farmers who plan to vote for Republican say they still have faith their economic pain will be short-lived. They highlight new negotiations with the European Union, Japan and U.K. as a sign of forward progress and support the tariffs as necessary to protect U.S. national security. They also point to the Agriculture Department‚Äôs $12 billion aid package as evidence of how the Trump administration isn‚Äôt going to let them fall behind. Link in bio for more. üì∏ AP Photo

The Congressional Black Caucus is demanding that an African-American lawmaker hold one of the top two leadership posts if Democrats win the House. It's a move that could set off a nasty internal fight within the party. ‚ÄúOver the past couple of weeks, several of our colleagues have respectfully shared letters of intent expressing interest in various House Democratic Caucus leadership positions,‚Äù said Rep. Cedric Richmond (left), CBC chairman, wrote in a "Dear Colleague" letter. ‚ÄúIt is within that context that I‚Äôd like to reiterate that if there is any change in our top leadership positions the Democratic Members of the CBC endorse African-American representation in at least one of the two top positions of elected House Democratic Caucus leadership.‚Äù
üî∏
The CBC action is seen as a potential threat to House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi of California and Minority Whip Steny Hoyer of Maryland who have been slotted to return as speaker and House majority leader, respectively, if Democrats gain the majority on Nov. 6. Hoyer, especially, could be the one to face a potential challenger if the CBC backs up its threat, according to Democratic insiders. Rep. Jim Clyburn (right) is the No. 3 House Democrat. He challenged Hoyer for the No. 2 post after the Democrats lost the House majority in 2010 but later backed down. Clyburn has been expected to run for majority whip if Democrats win on Tuesday. üì∏ AP Photo

After a violent week that included the arrest of a man charged with sending pipe bombs to prominent Democrats and Trump critics, the murder of 11 Jewish worshipers, and the killing of two African-Americans in a Kentucky grocery store that appeared to be racially motivated, a new poll shows most voters think President Trump has done more to divide the country than unite it. But voters think the national news media are even worse. üî∏
Just 3 in 10 voters, 30 percent, said Trump has done more to unite the country, compared with 56 percent who said he‚Äôs done more to divide it. Even more voters, 64 percent, said the media have done more to divide the country, while only 17 percent say they have done more to unite it. Link in bio for more from our latest poll.

In 1992 a historic number of women were elected to Congress, and it was widely considered the ‚Äúyear of the woman.‚Äù Now, 2018 has that same potential. There‚Äôs an unprecedented number of female candidates, and women also seem to be fired up to hit the polls.
üî∏
If you‚Äôre a woman and you‚Äôre voting in the midterm election, we want to hear from you. Call us (swipe üëà) and tell us what issues are motivating you to vote this year.
üî∏
(In this 1993 photo, then-first lady Hillary Clinton walks through the Capitol with several female senators who were elected during the ‚Äúyear of the woman‚Äù: Carol Mosley Braun, Barbara Boxer and Dianne Feinstein. Barbara Mikulski, who was elected in 1986 and is the longest serving female lawmaker, is also pictured. üì∏ Getty Images

With the White House all decked out for Halloween, President Trump and first lady Melania Trump welcomed trick-or-treaters over the weekend. Wonder Woman, a pair of astronauts, a storm trooper and more all came by for Halloween candy. üì∏ Getty Images

Retired Nevada Sen. Harry Reid offered perhaps his harshest criticism of President Trump yet on Wednesday. Reid said Trump is "profoundly wrong" after the president quoted his 1993 position on revoking birthright citizenship. In a statement, Reid said, "around the time Donald Trump was gobbling up tax-free inheritance money from his wealthy father and driving several companies into bankruptcy, I made a mistake" by proposing a bill to remove birthright citizenship from immigrants who entered the country illegally. In a speech on the Senate floor 25 years ago, Reid said "no sane country" would offer a "reward for being an illegal immigrant." Link in bio for the full story. üì∏ Getty Images

Kellyanne Conway said Wednesday morning that Democrats' refusal to accept the president's offers on DACA, the visa lottery, chain migration and the wall are why he now wants to unilaterally eliminate birthright citizenship.

The counselor to the president then said Democrats critical of Trump on border policy have flip flopped in the past.
üî∏
"I do love President Obama's comments in 2005 about cracking down on employers that want to hire illegals that don't cross the border legally just like Harry Reid in the past has talked about birthright citizenship," Conway said.
üî∏
"I think the Democrats just have amnesia when it comes to what they want to believe before they ran all the way to the left."
üî∏

The woman, who identified herself as Lorraine D. Parsons, emailed a number of journalists that a man named Bill Christensen knew exactly how much credit card debt she had and was willing to pay off $34,000‚Äî in addition to writing her a check for $20,000 if she made allegations. She also said Christensen offered her another $10,000 bonus from his client, Republican lobbyist Jack Burkman.

House Speaker Paul Ryan on Tuesday broke with President Trump on whether an executive order could deny citizenship to babies born in the U.S. to noncitizen parents. President Trump visited North Carolina to stump for GOP candidate Mark Harris in a race that arguably should never have been competitive. President Trump was slated for more than nine hours of ‚ÄúExecutive Time,‚Äù a euphemism for the unstructured time Trump spends tweeting, phoning friends and watching television last Tuesday.
