üî∏
A review of one week of the president‚Äôs private detailed schedules, from Monday Oct. 22 through Friday Oct. 26, showed the president had more free time on Tuesday than on any other day that week, but his Tuesday agenda was hardly atypical. And while the notion of Executive Time and the president‚Äôs increasingly late start to the day has come under scrutiny over the past year, this new batch of schedules we obtained gives fresh insight into the extent to which that unscheduled time dominates Trump‚Äôs week and is shaping his presidency. His schedule allows his whims and momentary interests to drive White House business. Link in bio for the full story. üì∏ AP Photo

These tactical and strategic victories have been the lifeblood of his government career. When he was a State Department official under President George W. Bush, he loved nothing more than sabotaging international agreements that he felt undermined America‚Äôs sovereignty and security.

Now that Bolton is President Donald Trump‚Äôs national security adviser, Christmas has been coming early and often. Bush administration. ‚ÄúToday, he is able to move forward.‚Äù Link to the full story in our bio.

Andrew Gillum, Florida‚Äôs Democratic gubernatorial nominee, accepted tickets to the Broadway show "Hamilton" from an undercover FBI agent. üî∏
Gillum has not publicly been accused of wrongdoing as part of that probe, but the cloud of the investigation has hung over his campaign. The issue has already been front and center in the tight gubernatorial race, in which Gillum became the surprise Democratic nominee. The document drop comes as more than 1 million voters have already cast ballots by mail, or at early voting sites, but one day ahead of Wednesday‚Äôs final gubernatorial debate between Gillum and GOP candidate Ron DeSantis, an event that will now likely place a statewide focus on Gillum‚Äôs role in the Corey records. üì∏ AP Photo

Here‚Äôs what you need to know about the Central American migrant caravan heading toward the southern U.S. border.
üî∏
Who organized or caused the caravan‚ùì
Bartolo Fuentes, an activist and former Honduran lawmaker. In an October 4 Facebook post, he shared a graphic promoting a ‚ÄúCaminata del Migrante‚Äù (‚ÄúMigrant March‚Äù).
üî∏
Is this the biggest migratory caravan on record‚ùì
Mass migration in itself ‚Äî even from Central America ‚Äî is nothing new. Hundreds of thousands of Salvadorans, Guatemalans, and Nicaraguans fled north to the U.S. and Mexico in the 1980s as those nations experienced brutal civil wars.
Caravans from Honduras have occurred since the late 1990s, but this appears to be the biggest, according to Andrew Selee, president of the nonpartisan Migration Policy Institute.
üî∏
What‚Äôs the principal reason migrants are traveling to the U.S.‚ùì
Experts say violence, poverty and family connections in the U.S. are the primary reasons driving migrants from Honduras, Guatemala and El Salvador ‚Äì as well as the possibility they might be able to stay once they arrive.
üî∏
What will a caravan member have to demonstrate to be admitted to the U.S. as an asylum seeker‚ùì
A person who enters the U.S. without authorization and seeks asylum must prove he or she has ‚Äúcredible fear‚Äù of persecution in his or her home country. The test is the first step in an asylum claim and could allow a migrant to remain in the U.S. pending a court date.
üî∏
How will the migrants be greeted at the border by the U.S. government‚ùì
Trump has threatened to send the military to the border and shut it down before the migrants can enter. The president already ordered up to 4,000 National Guard troops to the border in the spring (roughly 2,100 are currently deployed), but there‚Äôs nothing they can do to discourage asylum seekers.
In many cases, families surrender themselves at the border and claim asylum, which means more enforcement power won‚Äôt stop them.
Link to the full story in our bio. (üì∑ Getty)

Trump says Democrats are the party of ‚Äúobstruct and delay,‚Äù but he may be forced to work with them next year if he wants to achieve any of his legislative goals ‚Äî from winning approval for a renegotiated North American Free Trade Agreement to lowering drug prices. Sandra Day O‚ÄôConnor, the first woman to serve on the Supreme Court, has been diagnosed with ‚Äúthe beginning stages of dementia‚Äù and ‚Äúprobably Alzheimer‚Äôs disease,‚Äù she wrote in a letter, which comes a day after the Associated Press reported that O‚ÄôConnor, 88, had stepped back from public life. O‚ÄôConnor noted that her diagnosis has not ‚Äúdiminished my gratitude and deep appreciation for the countless blessings in my life.‚Äù ‚ÄúHow fortunate I feel to be an American and to have been presented with the remarkable opportunities available to the citizens of our country,‚Äù she wrote. ‚ÄúAs a young cowgirl from the Arizona desert, I never could have imagined that one day I would become the first woman justice on the U.S. Supreme Court.‚Äù Full story in bio. üì∏ Getty Images

üî∏
Lawmakers were universal in expressing doubts about the kingdom's official explanation, which attributed Khashoggi‚Äôs death to a fight that broke out in the Saudi consulate in Istanbul and which offered no credible explanation of why, for example, medical help was not sought for him. Turkish reports indicated Khashoggi was dismembered after being killed.
üî∏
The bipartisan criticism could prompt the Trump administration to go further than it has wanted to in responding to the international incident, exposing the crown prince to an increasing threat of U.S. sanctions.
üî∏
Sen. Bob Corker, the top Republican on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said Sunday he believes the crown prince directed Khashoggi's murder. "Obviously, if he's gone forth and murdered this journalist, he's now crossed the line,‚Äù Corker said. ‚ÄúAnd there has to be a punishment and a price paid for that.‚Äù Link in bio for the full story. üì∑ Getty Images

Roughly 700,000 people rallied in central London on Saturday to call for a new referendum on Brexit, according to the People‚Äôs Vote campaign.
üî∏
The group argues that Prime Minister Theresa May is negotiating a bad deal with the EU and voters should have the final say on the outcome of the talks. May has ruled out a second referendum, saying the result of the 2016 vote to leave the European Union should be respected.

London Mayor Sadiq Khan was among the speakers who addressed the crowd this weekend. He argued that ‚Äúthis vital issue‚Äù must be ‚Äútaken out of the hands of the politicians and returned to the British people.‚Äù Link in bio for the full story. üì∑ Getty Images

It looks like Democrats are poised to chip away at Republican dominance in governor‚Äôs seats across the country. Three GOP-controlled governorships ‚Äî Illinois, Michigan and New Mexico ‚Äî are expected to flip to Democratic hands. In Illinois, J.B. Pritzker (pictured) has been leading incumbent GOP Gov. Bruce Rauner nearly the whole campaign.

Meanwhile, Republicans are trying to flip a few solidly blue states red. Their best shot is in Oregon with GOP candidate Knute Buehler (swipe üëà), but the last time Oregon elected a Republican governor was in 1982.

New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio‚Äôs first major attempt to be a national player was a monthslong comedy of errors. It involved City Hall staffers and some of the biggest political operatives in New York, according to thousands of pages of emails we reviewed.  De Blasio‚Äôs Progressive Agenda nonprofit was seemingly designed to champion issues the mayor held dear ‚Äî income inequality, voter enfranchisement, education ‚Äî with de Blasio as the central force behind the ‚Äúmovement.‚Äù But the more-than-$860,000 effort yielded little in the end ‚Äî no public debates, a couple of events including one that failed spectacularly, and no political upside for a mayor singularly obsessed with becoming a national liberal leader. A PSA on the Mueller report: Prepare for disappointment. Cathy McMorris Rodgers, the most powerful woman in the GOP leadership, is on the defensive on health care. A mother of three, including a child with Down syndrome, McMorris Rodgers is often portrayed as a more compassionate face of a party that‚Äôs shifted hard to the right in the Trump-era. But she‚Äôs also the only Washington state lawmaker to have voted to repeal Obamacare last year. Now, she faces attack ads spotlighting that vote, not to mention lawn signs imploring voters to ‚Äúrepeal McMorris Rodgers, not our health care.‚Äù üì∏ AP Photo

So will Bernie Sanders run for president in 2020? Many of his former staffers hope he won't. They think a younger candidate who can continue what he started would be a better choice. But still, it's unclear who could carry that torch. There's a lot of talk about Elizabeth Warren, but other former Sanders staffers say that no other Democrat has emerged who matches Bernie. Link in bio for the full story. üì∑: Getty

New Jersey Gov. Phil Murphy‚Äôs administration hired a former campaign aide for a state job despite an allegation of sexual assault. Alvarez until Oct. 2, but he insisted members of his staff had properly handled the matter after it was brought to their attention in March. His transition team, he said, was another story. Recreational weed is now legal in Canada, which means Washington now has some major peer pressure to embrace the bong. It's unclear whether the push to liberalize U.S. marijuana laws will get very far: Attorney General Jeff Sessions has declared war on marijuana, though his efforts have been slowed by a not-so-hostile White House. Kamala Harris is offering the strongest sign yet that she's running for president in 2020. Harris hasn't officially announced her 2020 candidacy yet, but all the signs point in that direction ‚Äì especially when you look at her travel schedule. It's not a good week for Sen. Heidi Heitkamp, who's the most vulnerable Democratic senator facing reelection in November. Kevin Cramer ‚Äì and it included names of several women without their permission. ‚ÄúI deeply regret this mistake and we are in the process of issuing a retraction, personally apologizing to each of the people impacted by this and taking the necessary steps to ensure this never happens again,‚Äù Heitkamp said.

Nancy Pelosi is laser focused. With 21 days until the election, Pelosi gave us the details of her plans if Dems win back the House majority. The grand made-for-media move is being seen as a sign that Warren is getting ready to run for president in 2020. Playing consoler in chief following major storms seems to be President Trump‚Äôs new pastime. An upbeat Trump toured a Florida neighborhood wrecked by Hurricane Michael, with downed trees, damaged roofs and a deserted school. He greeted neighbors, passed out water bottles and posed for selfies at an aide distribution center with a very friendly crowd including one onlooker who vowed to vote for Republicans in the midterm elections.

The optics have been different than the images that emerged from past tours of disaster areas, where cable news channels and late night hosts picked up on scenes that made the president look out of touch or unrelatable ‚Äî the president tossing paper towels to Hurricane Maria victims, or handing a bucket to a pickup truck driver instead of placing it in the back. The administration has sought to avoid such coverage by demonstrating ‚Äî via frequent news conferences, through surrogates and on social media ‚Äî that the president and top officials are on top of things, one official said. A ‚Äúsuspicious envelope‚Äù was sent to GOP Sen. Susan Collins‚Äô home in Bangor, Maine, according to the local police. There are an unprecedented number of women running for Congress this year. There are female candidates in almost half of all House races and 17 percent of all Senate races. We used our race ratings to predict how likely it is that women will surpass their current count of 107 seats in Congress ‚Äî 84 in the House and 23 in the Senate, and while there is a good chance that women will see gains in the House, women in the Senate are likely to struggle to maintain their numbers. The Senate stands to gain only three extra women if female candidates win all of their competitive races.
üî∏
Democratic women running for seats in the House outnumber female Republican candidates by more than three to one. So if there is a blue wave this November, women (and especially women of color) are going to be the ones to drive it. Watch our Instagram story for more.

Ex-Senate aide James Wolfe pleaded guilty on Monday to lying to federal investigators about his contacts with reporters. Wolfe admitted to a single felony count of making a false statement in the course of a federal investigation. The false-statement charge Wolfe pleaded guilty to appears to specifically involve his denial of involvement in leaks about former Trump campaign adviser Carter Page and Senate plans to summon Page for an interview. Wolfe‚Äôs guilty plea could ease tensions between President Trump and the Justice Department since Trump has been pressing for a crackdown on leaks.
üî∏
During the 45-minute-long hearing, Wolfe grew emotional at times. On several occasions, he took long pauses as he was questioned about whether he understood the consequences of pleading guilty and the rights he was giving up. Wolfe appeared to wipe away tears at one point, although he faced the judge and away from the audience. One of Wolfe‚Äôs lawyers, Preston Burton, fetched some tissues to comfort the defendant. Under federal sentencing guidelines, Wolfe is likely to receive between zero and six months in prison. The maximum possible sentence is five years and a $250,000 fine. üì∏ Getty Images

Donald Trump suggested that "rogue killers" may be responsible for the disappearance of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi. Trump said that he spoke with Saudi Arabia's King Salman who "flatly denied"  any knowledge of what happened Khashoggi, who is known for being writing critically of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and other members of the royal family.

Trump also said that Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is heading to Saudi Arabia today to meet with King Salman. ‚ÄúWe are going to leave nothing uncovered," Trump said. Trump and his aides, including son-in-law, Jared Kushner, have cultivated closer ties with the Saudi royal family and have announced billions of dollars in arms sales. Today marks 27 years since Clarence Thomas was narrowly confirmed to the Supreme Court. His confirmation process was almost derailed after a woman accused him of sexual harassment. Her name: Anita Hill.
üî∏
Hill took a polygraph and publicly testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee about alleged sexual misconduct when she worked for him 10 years earlier. Thomas hit back and said it was all part of a larger attempt to prevent an African American conservative from filling Thurgood Marshall's liberal seat.
üî∏
Thomas was ultimately confirmed 52-48, which back in 1991 was the narrowest margin for approval of a Supreme Court justice in more than a century. That record was broken this month when Brett Kavanaugh was confirmed by an even closer 50-48 after a sexual assault allegation from Dr. Christine Blasey Ford.
üî∏
Clarence Thomas is now the longest serving justice on the Supreme Court.

Sen. Elizabeth Warren released DNA test results today that ‚Äústrongly support‚Äù her claims of Native American ancestry, hitting back at Trump and showing her seriousness about a 2020 presidential run. The test was conducted by a Stanford University professor and shows Warren‚Äôs likely Native American ancestry dates back six to 10 generations.
üî∏
Trump and others have suggested that Warren played up or invented her Native American ancestry. The president has often mocked Warren as ‚ÄúPocahontas" and in July he said he would donate $1 million to Warren's charity of choice if she took a DNA test. Trump seemed dismissive today of Warren's test results, saying ‚ÄúWho cares?‚Äù Link in bio for the full story.

Pennsylvania helped win Trump the presidency in 2016. But now it could be ground zero for a 2018 Democratic comeback. Tom Wolf (üëà) have double-digit leads over their GOP challengers, according to our latest poll. Turkey imprisoned the evangelical faith leader and his wife, Norine, in October 2016, along with 20 other Americans, following a failed coup attempt against President Recep Tayyip Erdoƒüan. Rev. Andrew Brunson has been released by Turkish authorities after being held on espionage charges for more than two years. The Turkish court released Brunson from house arrest but convicted him of a ‚Äúterror‚Äù charge, AP reported.

Norine Brunson was released after 13 days. Andrew Brunson was held in prison until July, when Turkish officials moved him to house arrest. His case became a cause c√©l√®bre among Christian evangelicals, including Vice President Mike Pence, and a political rallying cry for Trump, who was propelled to office in part by the evangelical vote. üì∏ Getty Images

The GOP is betting big on an ad strategy that demonizes two of the most recognizable women in American politics: Nancy Pelosi and Hillary Clinton. Democrats ‚Äî and even some Republicans ‚Äî question whether the familiar blueprint will backfire since it doesn‚Äôt account for 2018‚Äôs unique conditions or new motivations stirring women in a post-Brett Kavanaugh election. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got 30,000 women running nationwide and they‚Äôre still running against Nancy Pelosi and Hillary Clinton,‚Äù said Sue Dvorsky, former Iowa Democratic Party chair. ‚ÄúIs that the best they‚Äôve got?‚Äù Kim Reem, member at large of the National Federation of Republican Women sees the reasoning for having Pelosi in ads but questions using Clinton this cycle. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no doubt about it that they‚Äôre polarizing. But where is Hillary on the ballot? She‚Äôs not.‚Äù Link in bio for the full story. üì∏ AP Image

If North Dakota Sen. Heidi Heitkamp loses her race, Democrats can all but kiss their hopes of winning the Senate goodbye. Republicans have closed in on the seat, and think they‚Äôre on the cusp of delivering a knockout blow. Heitkamp is down in public polls by a significant margin against her opponent Rep. Kevin Cramer, but she recently hinted that she believes Cramer could suffer from self-inflicted wounds. In a story published last weekend, Cramer told The New York Times that sexual assault accusations and the #MeToo campaign against Kavanaugh were a ‚Äúmovement toward victimization‚Äù of men. He also was scolded by Canadians over his comments about new NAFTA negotiations.
üî∏
‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a level of arrogance and rash statements that doesn‚Äôt reflect the typical North Dakota, common-sense contemplative, work-together kind of attitude,‚Äù Heitkamp said. ‚ÄúYou can say all these crazy things, but sometimes the crazy things you say and how you behave has real consequences here.‚Äù
üî∏

Hurricane Maria barreled through Puerto Rico one year ago today. As the island continues to recover from the devastating storm that killed nearly 3,000 people, we look back at photos that our photographer Scott Mahaskey took when he visited the island in December 2017. Mahaskey and reporter Lorraine Woellert found that the storm exposed an open secret generations in the making: Tens of thousands of island residents were, in fact, squatters, living illegally on abandoned or government land. For years, squatters were ignored or used as political pawns as the bankrupt central government swung from crisis to crisis. That changed with Maria, which tore through the low-lying barrios. After Maria, with no legal claim to their homes or the land they‚Äôre built on, squatters found themselves without federal aid, falling through the cracks of post-disaster housing assistance. Because they‚Äôre neither renters nor owners, they were cut off from programs that finance rebuilding or major repairs. üëÜLink in bio for the full story. üì∏ M. Scott Mahaskey/POLITICO

Lee Francis Cissna is the son of an immigrant and the son-in-law of a refugee. So why is he making it so much harder for immigrants to come to the United States? üî∏The establishment of a task force that pledges to investigate immigration fraud and strip away citizenship in such cases‚Äîsomething that‚Äôs historically been reserved for serious criminals or terrorists.
üî∏The creation of a new memo that allows visa officers to deny applications without first requesting more evidence or notifying an applicant.
üî∏The decimation of the refugee program, slashing the level of admissions and redirecting its resources to domestic asylum cases.
üîπ
When a White House reporter asked whether Cissna‚Äôs own mother and mother-in-law would have been able to enter the U.S. under the changes he was proposing. He dodged the question, saying that policymakers ‚Äúshould not be handicapped or shackled‚Äù by the fact that their own families may have benefited from a certain program. üëÜLink in bio for immigration reporter Ted Hesson‚Äôs profile of Lee Francis Cissna. üì∏ AP Photo

‚ÄúI‚Äôve always made more money in bad markets than in good markets.‚Äù These are the words Donald Trump said just over 10 years ago, on the eve of a global financial crisis that spiraled out of control.
üî∏
Wall Street crashed. $19 trillion in household wealth disappeared. And more than 8 million Americans ended up losing their jobs. But in the middle of the deepest economic crisis since the Great Depression, Trump and his administration's top financial advisers found something: a chance to get richer.

Steven Mnuchin, now the Treasury secretary, led a group of investors who bought a failed thrift with government help and sold it for a profit. ‚ÄúWe might as well have a big red X on the bottom of this plane. Today marks 17 years since the horrific terrorist attacks that killed nearly 3,000 people on U.S. soil. And within days of the attacks, an idea was born that would change the very structure of the U.S. government: the creation of what would become the Department of Homeland Security. üî∏
Just 11 days after September 11, 2001, Pennsylvania Governor Tom Ridge was appointed as the first Director of the Office of Homeland Security in the White House. The goal: To safeguard the country against terrorism and respond to any future attacks. It officially became a stand-alone, Cabinet-level department in March 2003 after the Homeland Security Act passed Congress in late 2002. üî∏
Ridge‚Äôs seat is now held by Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen.

President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed the Social Security Act on this day 83 years ago. Social security was a key element of Roosevelt‚Äôs New Deal program to provide economic and social aid after the Great Depression. For more than eight decades, the program has secured Americans‚Äô right to disability and unemployment benefits, but in more recent years the federal government‚Äôs largest benefit program has faced serious financial problems due to the country‚Äôs aging population and the program‚Äôs inability to generate enough revenue.

Former President Richard Nixon resigned halfway through his second term on this day 44 years ago. Rather than face impeachment over his efforts to cover up illegal activities by members of his administration, Nixon appeared on national television August 8, 1974 to announce that his resignation would take effect the following day at noon. The photograph of him giving a thumbs up after his announcement has since immortalized the 37th president as the only U.S. Commander in Chief thus far to resign. (üì∑:Getty)

We now have new insights into what Putin and Trump talked about in their private meeting last month. A leaked Russian document that we obtained shows Putin presented Trump with a series of requests including new talks on controlling nuclear arms and prohibiting weapons in space. 
The document outlines several areas where the two countries could work together to reduce nuclear dangers and rebuild lost trust, starting with extending the New START treaty, which was signed by Putin and Obama in 2010. It limits the number of nuclear warheads for each country and allows vigorous regular inspections. 
More controversially, the document outlines Moscow‚Äôs pitch to ‚Äúreaffirm commitment‚Äù to agreements covering ‚Äúintermediate-range missiles.‚Äù And it also raises the prospect of a new space treaty that bars both nations from placing weapons in orbit. 
Link in bio for our exclusive story. üì∑: @gettyimages

A woman whose son was killed on Mexican soil by a U.S. Border Patrol agent in Arizona can sue for damages, a federal court ruled Tuesday. The U.S. Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that Border Patrol agent Lonnie Swartz is not entitled to qualified immunity, saying that the Fourth Amendment ‚Äî which prohibits unreasonable searches and seizures ‚Äî applies in this case. Swartz, who was found not guilty in April of second-degree murder for the 2012 shooting, has said he shot at people throwing rocks through the border fence in Nogales, Arizona. A retrial in the case will take place in October. Jose Antonio Elena Rodr√≠guez, 16, was hit mostly in the back by about 10 bullets, according to the court ruling. Swartz fired between 14 to 30 bullets at Rodr√≠guez. In the lawsuit filed by Araceli Rodriguez, mother of Jose Antonio Elena Rodr√≠guez, she says her son was "peacefully walking down the Calle Internacional, a street in Nogales, Mexico," according to the opinion. She said the 16-year-old was not throwing rocks and was not engaging in any illegal behavior. üì∑@APnews

Happy birthday Robert Mueller! The special counsel turns 74 years old today. Did you know former Secretary of State John Kerry was reportedly one of Mueller‚Äôs classmates at St. Paul‚Äôs boarding school? The two played on the school‚Äôs sports teams together. Mueller first joined the DOJ in 1989 to lead the prosecution of Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. He later became FBI director under George W. Bush in 2001, and was the longest serving FBI director since J. Edgar Hoover. After leaving his post in 2013, Mueller returned to the spotlight on May 17, 2017, when the DOJ tasked Mueller with leading the investigation of Russia‚Äôs interference in the 2016 election.

Simon & Schuster, Bob Woodward‚Äôs publisher, announced Monday that it plans to release his 19th book, entitled ‚ÄúFear: Trump in the White House,‚Äù on Sept. 11. But the process for managing the book has not been as formal in President Donald Trump‚Äôs White House ‚Äì in fact, there hasn‚Äôt been any process at all. According to half a dozen former administration officials and people close to the administration, Woodward was never officially granted access to the White House or to the president, and the communications department did nothing to help him in researching or writing his book. As the U.S. begins the ‚Äúlargest trade war in history,‚Äù China is taking aim at Trump country. This could cut deep into the incomes of farmers, ranchers and agribusinesses. China buys nearly one-third of all U.S. soybeans. It's the largest customer for cherry producers in the Pacific Northwest. And it's the No. 2 export destination for U.S. pork.

Contact between the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and six of the largest U.S. banks seems to increase around the Fed‚Äôs key interest-rate-setting meetings, according to a new academic study that raises questions about whether this could give top Wall Street institutions an unfair competitive edge. 
The study, from the University of Chicago‚Äôs Booth School of Business, examines granular data on cab rides released by New York‚Äôs taxi regulator. It singles out lunchtime trips between the New York Fed and the major offices of six banks: Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase, Morgan Stanley, Bank of New York Mellon and Bank of America. üî∏
It also includes potential off-site meetups by factoring in "coincidental drop-offs," where someone from the New York Fed and someone from a bank each appeared to be dropped off at the same location around the same time. üî∏
Lunchtime coincidental drop-offs happened about 50 percent more often between when an important meeting of the policy-making Federal Open Market Committee started through the following week, according to the study written by David Andrew Finer. That's an average of about 1.2 more taxi rides per meeting. üî∏ ‚ÄúI cannot conclusively demonstrate a link between rides and face-to-face meetings, but evidence that individuals are in very close proximity to each other more often around FOMC meetings would complement more indirect evidence of regular informal communication,‚Äù the study says. It examines taxi data between 2009, when data was first made available, and 2014, before ride shares like Uber and Lyft became popular. ‚ÄîVICTORIA GUIDA üì∑Andrew Brannan via Flickr

Which came first, the Donald or the tweet? Unlike the great poultry conundrum, we know the answer to this one. Donald Trump was well into thick-waisted middle age by the time Twitter launched in 2006, and he had passed the 60 mark when, three years later, he issued his first tweet under the @realDonaldTrump moniker. Yet Trump‚Äôs Twitter feed and his psyche are now so fused that it‚Äôs hard to tell where one ends and the other begins‚Äîor if such a boundary even exists. Not since Mussolini mounted his Roman balcony has a national leader merged so completely with a communication platform.
üî∏
The president‚Äôs Twitter fixation gives the lie to the notion that social networks are preserves of the tech-adept young. Although Trump, according to press reports, rarely uses computers, sends emails, or goes online, he‚Äôs found a match in Twitter. It‚Äôs a technology perfectly suited to his need for attention and, more ominously, his recklessness. By blurring private and public discourse, Twitter allows Trump to turn locker-room talk, his favored idiom, into presidential speech. And it enables him to manhandle the public‚Äôs attention, constantly yanking the media spotlight back on himself whenever it starts to wander. -NICHOLAS CARR üì∑ POLITICO illustration / @istockbygettyimages 
#thefridaycover #longreads #donaldtrump #presidenttrump #trump #twitter #socialmedia #addiction #magazine #magazinecover #politics

"The U.S. government hasn't tested these plans in 30 years,‚Äù said the senior administration official involved in the White House response. ‚ÄúAll the fresh faces sitting around the table in the situation room have little idea what their roles would be in this scenario. üî∏
Top administration officials had always said they would eradicate the law through both legislative and executive actions, but they never provided the public with anything close to the detailed blueprint shared with the members of the House Freedom Caucus, whose confidence ‚Äî and votes ‚Äî President Donald Trump was trying to win at the time. The blueprint, built off the executive order to minimize Obamacare‚Äôs ‚Äúeconomic burden,‚Äù which Trump signed just hours after taking the oath of office, shows just how advanced the administration‚Äôs plans to unwind the law were ‚Äî plans that would become far more important after the legislative efforts to repeal Obamacare failed.

Mass confusion is erupting in town halls across the country thanks to the new tax law, as tens of thousands of property owners scramble to pay next year‚Äôs taxes ahead of schedule ‚Äî while the governors of their states and the IRS give conflicting signals about whether that‚Äôs even allowed.
üî∏
In the Albany suburb of Bethlehem, New York, more than 100 people waited in a gym to pay their property tax bills Thursday ‚Äî some of them for over an hour ‚Äî before a new federal $10,000 cap on state and local deductions goes into effect Jan. 1. Municipalities on Long Island were preparing to open over the weekend to give taxpayers more time to pay. But the IRS issued an edict Wednesday night saying the early payments could be deducted on 2017 taxes only if they had already been assessed. That threw residents and local government officials into a new round of confusion as everyone scrambled to determine which payments would qualify.
üî∏
The uncertainty this week could be the first of many misunderstandings to come as new tax rules take effect starting New Year‚Äôs Day. The tax law that President Donald Trump signed Dec. 22, which Congress rushed to pass before the end of the year, is explicit in some of its language but vague in other areas. It explicitly forbade prepayments of state and local income taxes but was silent on prepayments for state and local property taxes. -AARON LORENZO üì∑: @gettyimages

One of the bizarro lessons of our bizarro time is that inside every taciturn lawperson is a tweeting fool who longs to go wild with emoji, memes and subtweets thick with innuendo.
üî∏
These days, when notable squares‚ÄîPreet Bharara (joined February 2017), Walter Shaub (joined February 2017), Sally Yates (joined June 2017), Renato Mariotti (joined July 2017), John Brennan (joined September 2017)‚Äîexit the discretion of a law firm or a government office, they strap on their dancing shoes and head to the Twitter disco. And off they go, posting selfies and threads, joking about the banality of bots, unpacking l‚ÄôAffaire Russe and, of course, sniping at Alan Dershowitz. It‚Äôs now hard to remember Twitter before the newly liberated JDs and ex-agency heads arrived. Their passion for the weirdness of the platform is precious, and useful. I hope they never go away.
üî∏
One of the more intriguing lawman-newcomers to Twitter is James Comey, an American citizen so pious he once taught Sunday school. While some of the nation‚Äôs other high clerics, disinhibited by the pounding Twitter beats, goof around, rib one another, advertise themselves and pounce on every table scrap from the news banquet, Comey has chosen to play the platform a little bit differently. Once or twice a week the former FBI director expresses himself in pensive photos and sententious needlepoint quotations about the importance of leadership, justice and goodness. He is a man using Twitter not to connect but to disconnect‚Äîto position himself as singularly wise, a sermonizer in possession of a privileged relationship to truth itself. - VIRGINIA HEFFERNAN (via @politicomag) üì∑: POLITICO illustration / @gettyimages

üî∏

For House Speaker Paul Ryan, it‚Äôs the culmination of a career-long pursuit of overhauling the tax code.
üî∏ ‚ÄúThis is a day I have looked forward to for a very long time,‚Äù he said on the House floor. ‚ÄúToday is about how much better things can be: More jobs, fairer taxes, and bigger paychecks. The Supreme Court is taking up a case that could make sports betting widely available.
üî∏ 
The case the justices are hearing Monday is a result of New Jersey's yearslong effort to bring betting on sports to its casinos and racetracks. New Jersey is challenging a federal law that bars states from authorizing sports gambling. If the Supreme Court strikes down the law, giving sports betting the go-ahead, 32 states would likely offer it within five years, according to one report.
The case pits New Jersey and other states against all four major U.S. professional sports leagues, the NCAA and the federal government. The stakes are high. The American Gaming Association estimates that Americans illegally wager about $150 billion on sports each year.
üî∏ 
In court, the NBA, NFL, NHL and Major League Baseball have fought New Jersey's gambling expansion, arguing that it would hurt the integrity of their games, though leaders of all but the NFL have shown varying degrees of openness to legalized sports gambling.
üî∏ 
More than a dozen states are supporting New Jersey, which is arguing that Congress exceeded its authority when it passed a 1992 law that keeps states from authorizing sports betting. The state says the Constitution allows Congress to make wagering on sports illegal itself but that it can't require states to keep sports gambling prohibitions in place.
üî∏ 
Now that the case is before the Supreme Court, the justices could ultimately greenlight the expansion of sports gambling nationwide by striking down the federal law. But the justices could also uphold it, leaving in place the status quo, or rule narrowly that what New Jersey did didn't violate the law.
üî∏ 
A decision is expected by the end of June. ‚ÄîAP üì∑: @AP.Images 
#sports #betting #sportsbetting #gambling #newjersey #scotus #supremecourt #sportsgambling

First lady Melania Trump has opted for a more traditional decor for her family's first Christmas in the White House, adding a few new touches to the standards.
üî∏ 
New this year are wreaths hanging from the exterior of every window. Another new touch are glistening wintry branches lining an East Wing hallway that leads guests to a tree decorated with the Trump family's official Christmas ornament, a gold-toned bauble featuring the presidential coat of arms surrounded by a wreath of holly.
üî∏ 
The family Christmas card is framed and on display. "Merry Christmas and Happy New Year," says the card signed by President Donald Trump, the first lady and Barron, their 11-year-old son.
üî∏ 
Among the Christmas standards is an 18-foot (about 5.5-meter) fir tree in its traditional spot in the Blue Room, decorated with ornaments bearing the seals of every state and U.S. territory.
üî∏ 
The 350-pound (about 160-kilogram) gingerbread house this year offers a view of the White House from the south.
üî∏ 
Her theme is "Time-Honored Traditions," which the White House said pays respect to 200 years of holiday traditions at the executive mansion.
üî∏ 
The first lady's office previewed the decorations for journalists on Monday after more than 150 volunteers from 29 states spent 1,600 hours during the long holiday weekend decking the White House halls. Mrs. Trump has also invited children and students from a nearby military base to come see the decorations and work on holiday arts and crafts.
üî∏ 
The White House said she personally chose every detail of the decor. She did a final check late Sunday after returning from the family's Thanksgiving at their home in Palm Beach, Florida.q
üî∏ 
Mrs. Trump's signature Christmas includes 71 wreaths, 53 Christmas trees, more than 18,000 lights, more than 12,000 ornaments, more than 3,100 yards (about 2800 meters) of ribbon and more than 1,000 feet (300 meters) of garland, the White House said. ‚ÄîAP üì∑: @AP.Images

Several months ago, Sen. Lamar Alexander phoned Education Secretary Betsy DeVos with a message: Back off.
üî∏
Alexander, the Republican chairman of the Senate HELP Committee, was furious that a top DeVos aide was circumventing a new law aimed at reducing the federal government‚Äôs role in K-12 education. He contended that the agency was out of bounds by challenging state officials, for instance, about whether they were setting sufficiently ambitious goals for their students.
üî∏

DeVos‚Äô agency quickly yielded to his interpretation of the law ‚Äî and she ‚Äúthanked me for it,‚Äù Alexander told POLITICO.
üî∏
Alexander‚Äôs heavy hand raises questions about who‚Äôs calling some of the shots at the Education Department, an agency he once headed ‚Äî and to which DeVos came with virtually no expertise in running government bureaucracies.
üî∏
DeVos has been a lightning rod in the education world and one of the most controversial members of President Donald Trump‚Äôs Cabinet. She made her name as a school choice activist and billionaire Republican donor before she was nominated to run the Education Department. With Alexander running the key Senate oversight committee, observers say he‚Äôs trying to keep her agency on a tight leash.
üî∏
But some see Alexander‚Äôs moves earlier this summer as presumptuous ‚Äî and believe they not only abruptly changed how the agency is enforcing the law, called the Every Student Succeeds Act, but could translate into little to no federal oversight of state education. Critics note the law imposed certain requirements to protect poor and minority students, whose performance often lags behind their peers'. They worry whether states will adequately track and provide equal opportunities for at-risk kids or face consequences from the Education Department if they fail to do that. ‚ÄîCAITLIN EMMA üì∑: @gettyimages

Ike Horst raises 22,000 turkeys a year on his farm in the rolling hills of south-central Pennsylvania, selling them to a processing company that was providing him with enough of a nest egg that he hoped he could sell the farm and retire.
üî∏ 
But a Trump administration decision to block proposed agriculture regulations may blow up those plans, preserving the multibillion-dollar meat industry‚Äôs power over the smaller turkey farmers whose birds will grace the tables in millions of American homes this Thanksgiving.
üî∏ 
Horst is one of the independent businessmen caught up in the Trump administration‚Äôs governmentwide deregulation frenzy.
üî∏ 
Obama-era rules that had yet to take effect would have given smaller farmers more power to set the terms of their deals with massive meat companies, empowering the growers to sue and better define abusive practices by processors and distributors under federal law. Trump‚Äôs Agriculture Department killed two of the proposed rules, one of which would have taken effect in October.
üî∏ 
Major agribusinesses like Cargill and Butterball fought the rules, saying they would lead to endless litigation between farmers and global food companies.
üî∏ 
Trump‚Äôs deregulatory strike ‚Äî lauded by big business ‚Äî has consequences, even for the mom-and-pop turkey farmers who raise free-range, antibiotic-free turkeys that have seen increasing demand as Americans become more socially conscious about the production of their foods.
üî∏ 
Horst is afraid a planned sale of his farm will fall through because Plainville Farms, a major organic food producer and the primary customer for his turkeys, is requiring the buyer to install upgrades including fans, tunnel ventilation and a stationary generator if it wants to continue supplying to the company.
üî∏ 
Under the rules Trump killed, Horst‚Äôs buyer could have resisted such new costs.
üî∏ "That was my retirement," said Horst, who is selling his farm for health reasons and is scheduled to close the sale in January. ‚ÄîCHRISTINE HAUGHNEY üì∑: @smahaskey/POLITICO

Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen announced Monday that she will leave the central bank once she steps down as Fed chief in early February, though her term on the board doesn't end until 2024.
üî∏ 
The announcement comes nearly three weeks after President Donald Trump decided to nominate Fed Governor Jerome Powell as the next U.S. central bank head, replacing Yellen with a similarly minded but Republican chairman.
üî∏ 
Yellen's move means the agency will have a fourth vacancy it needs to fill. Trump has already installed a vice chair of supervision, Randal Quarles, on the Fed's board and will have the opportunity to name his own vice chair and three more governors.
üî∏

üî∏ 
Carranza and Mnuchin, accompanied by his wife Louise Linton, examined sheets of the $1 bills at the bureau's Washington printing plant. The currency will be shipped to Federal Reserve regional banks around the country, and the new bills are expected to go into circulation in December.

Both Treasury officials provided 10 sample signatures, from which one was chosen for government engravers.

House Republicans cleared a crucial hurdle in their drive to overhaul the tax code Thursday after narrowly approving the Senate‚Äôs budget.
üî∏
By passing the measure, 216-212, Republicans unlocked procedural powers that allow the Senate to pass a tax bill with just 51 votes ‚Äî and evade Democratic filibusters. But even with the ability to sideline Democrats, the GOP faces a daunting task as it tries to rewrite the tax code.
üî∏
Heading into the vote, it was unclear whether enough GOP lawmakers would support the measure. A band of Republicans from high-tax states vowed to vote "no" on the budget unless GOP leaders scrapped plans to curb the state and local tax deduction currently in the GOP's tax proposal.
üî∏
Speaker Paul Ryan and his top lieutenants were banking, however, on enough Republicans being jazzed about tax reform to back a fiscal blueprint many despise.
üî∏
The vote was filled with drama on the House floor.

üèÖ Filipino veterans of World War II have been awarded the Congressional Gold Medal, 75 years after they joined with the United States to defeat Japan.
At a ceremony Wednesday at the Capitol, a group of veterans and family members of those who died belatedly received the medals, the nation's highest civilian award.
üî∏
More than 250,000 Filipino soldiers served alongside U.S. soldiers in World War II, including more than 57,000 who died. After the war ended, President Harry Truman signed laws that stripped away promises of benefits and citizenship for Filipino veterans.
üî∏
Only recently have the veterans won back some concessions and acknowledgment, including the gold medal. Some received lump-sum payments as part of the 2009 economic stimulus law.
üî∏
House Speaker Paul Ryan called Wednesday's ceremony "long, long overdue." ‚ÄîAP üì∑: @AP.Images

Japan exasperated by Trump‚Äôs trade policies üî∏üî∏üî∏ TOKYO ‚Äî Japanese officials are expressing growing frustration with the Trump administration‚Äôs economic policies, vowing to continue striking trade deals with other countries that undercut U.S. agricultural exports rather than seek a new trade agreement with the United States.
üî∏
The frustration comes both from President Donald Trump‚Äôs harsh rhetoric on trade and from his pullout from the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership, which Japan still hopes can provide a bulwark against China‚Äôs growing influence in the Asia-Pacific region.
üî∏
Meanwhile, there is growing evidence that the failure of the TPP is taking a sharp toll on rural America. In August, the volume of U.S. sales of pork to Japan dropped by 9 percent year over year, a serious blow to farmers who had been preparing for a big increase in sales because of lower tariffs in the TPP.
üî∏
Instead, other countries that export meats, grains and fruits have seized on their advantage over American growers and producers in the wake of the U.S. pullout from the TPP. And a new Reuters poll shows Trump‚Äôs favorability in rural America ‚Äî once a great stronghold ‚Äî dropped from 55 percent last winter to 47 percent in September. The poll also showed a plunge in support for Trump‚Äôs trade agenda among rural voters.
üî∏
Both Vice President Mike Pence and Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue ‚Äî who were widely known as free traders before working for Trump ‚Äî have pointed to the president‚Äôs desire for ‚Äúbeautiful‚Äù new trade deals to replace the TPP. Perdue said this month that crafting a new deal with Japan was a top priority. And on Monday, Pence will meet with his Japanese counterpart as part of an effort to reboot the economic relationship between the two countries. -ADAM BEHSUDI

Roger Stone finally came face to face Tuesday with the man he bad-mouthed for months: top House Democratic Russia investigator Rep. Adam Schiff. Schiff declined to say what question Stone wouldn't answer, but Stone himself told reporters: he wouldn't divulge the person who acted as his go-between with Wikileaks founder Julian Assange last year. Stone has come under scrutiny for seeming to predict Wikileaks' October dump of emails hacked from the account of Hillary Clinton's 2016 presidential campaign chairman, John Podesta. "I expressed my view that I‚Äôm aware of no evidence whatsoever of collusion by the Russian state or anyone in the Trump campaign or anyone associated with Donald Trump," Stone told reporters. The Senate's lone black Republican urged President Donald Trump on Wednesday to avoid inflammatory racial rhetoric such as his statement blaming "many sides" for the violence at a recent white nationalist protest in Virginia. "Racism is evil," Trump said in a statement from the White House. "And those who cause violence in its name are criminal and thugs, including the KKK, neo-Nazis, white supremacists and other hate groups that are repugnant to everything we hold dear as Americans." The president's new rhetoric comes days after violence occurred in Charlottesville, Virginia, where a group of white supremacists gathered to protest the removal of a statue of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee and clashed with counter-protesters. At least one person died when a car plowed through a crowd Saturday, injuring more than a dozen others. Two Virginia state troopers were also killed in a helicopter crash Saturday that was responding to the protest. üì∑: @AP.Images

The Justice Department is considering making changes to its policies on subpoenaing news organizations as part of its crackdown on government leaks, Attorney General Jeff Sessions said Friday.

Much of that effort involves investigating and prosecuting leak suspects, he said, but another aspect is ‚Äúreviewing policies affecting media subpoenas.‚Äù That review, he said, came at the suggestion of FBI agents, career investigators and prosecutors who have weighed in on the leak problem.
‚ÄúWe respect the important role that the press plays, and we'll give them respect, but it is not unlimited,‚Äù Sessions said. ‚ÄúThey cannot place lives at risk with impunity. New York Sen. Chuck Schumer stands at a lectern after announcing his Democratic leadership team in the Senate on Nov. 16, 2016. Illinois Sen. Dick Durbin will remain as minority whip, and Washington Sen. Patty Murray will become assistant leader. From @politico reporters Burgess Everett and Elana Schor: 
Senate Democrats have settled on a leadership team for the start of the Trump administration, appointing Sen. Patty Murray (D-Wash.) as assistant leader and elevating Sen. Bernie Sanders to a post in the caucus' senior ranks. 
The expanded leadership team tapped by newly elected Senate-Democratic leader Chuck Schumer gives both liberals and moderates fresh influence on internal decision-making in the wake of the party's Election Day drubbing. The selection of Murray as assistant leader heads off an internal fight with Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.), who will remain minority whip. 
All 10 members of the new Democratic slate will be invited to leadership meetings, a senior Democratic aide said. 
Schumer will be followed in the Democratic leadership hierarchy by Durbin, Murray and Sen. Debbie Stabenow, senators said. 
Sanders was given the post of outreach chair, while Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.) will be vice chair of the Democratic Policy and Communications Committee and Sen. Tammy Baldwin (D-Wisc.) will be secretary of the Senate Democratic conference.

#BREAKING: Under fire for bragging about sexual assault, @realdonaldtrump tried to redirect by holding a surprise panel, broadcast live to Facebook, with women who have accused Bill Clinton of sexual misconduct on Sunday evening, just an hour and a half before he was set to square off with @HillaryClinton in their second presidential debate.
Seated beside four women -- including Juanita Broaddrick, Paula Jones, Kathleen Willey and Kathy Shelton -- Trump addressed viewers ahead of the debate, making an issue of Bill Clinton‚Äôs own sexual history as the GOP nominee faces a mass defection from within his own party. ‚ÄúThese four very courageous women have asked to be here, and it was our honor to help them,‚Äù Trump said of the women who then excused his comments caught on tape and released on Friday. ‚ÄúActions speak louder than words,‚Äù said Broaddrick, who alleged in 1999 that Clinton raped her in 1978 -- a claim that Clinton has denied. ‚ÄúMr. Trump may have said some bad words, but Bill Clinton raped me and Hillary Clinton threatened me. I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs anything worse.‚Äù ‚ÄúI think they should all look at the fact that he is a good person,‚Äù Jones said of Trump.‚ÄúHe's not what other person have been saying he has been, like Hillary." Jones sued Bill Clinton for sexual harassment in 1994, and the case was settled without him admitting guilt.

No. 5 on the #POLITICO50 list: Sen. @elizabethwarrenma

After a surprisingly close Democratic primary in which @HillaryClinton, queen of the establishment, was nearly deposed by @BernieSanders, it‚Äôs clear something drastic has happened on the American left. That something is, in large part, the work of #ElizabethWarren.

Warren, a 67-year-old former Harvard Law professor, is a unique figure in #politics: She‚Äôs the actual author of the ideas‚Äînot just their publicist‚Äîwhose torch she now carries in Washington. Her legal career was built on documenting the way bankruptcy law hurts the American middle class, and by the time she entered politics after the financial crisis, she had developed a full-throated critique of the way the modern economy squeezes working families. From her platform in the Senate, she not only has won over liberals, but arguably drew the blueprint for a more progressive vision of the Democratic Party.

On policy, Warren has defined the terms that have shaped the 2016 presidential race. The ‚Äúrigged‚Äù economy? She began popularizing the notion in her 2012 Senate campaign announcement video. The Trans-Pacific Partnership? She marshaled liberal opposition to it, confronting President Obama over the trade deal in a public letter in April 2015. Debt-free college tuition? Warren beat Clinton and Sanders to the punch, introducing a framework in June 2015 for how the proposal would work.

What makes Warren truly formidable now is her capacity to marry policy prowess and backstage hardball, as well as a primal ability to rally Democratic lawmakers, donors and voters. All of which positions her to carry the Sanders mantle toward political reality. She now rivals the Obamas and Clintons as perhaps the most highly sought-after Democratic surrogate, has raised millions for more than a half-dozen Democratic Senate candidates and has put aside her Clinton skepticism to emerge as one of the party‚Äôs most effective Trump baiters‚Äîso angering the blustery Republican nominee that ‚ÄúPocahontas,‚Äù as he has dubbed her, has become one of his favorite Twitter targets.

Warren is gradually shaping the Democratic Party in her own image, which could be felt for years.

No. 10 on the #POLITICO50 list: Lin-Manuel Miranda

Every American with a pulse by now knows that Lin-Manuel Miranda‚Äôs musical #Hamilton is a Broadway sensation. Since its debut a year ago, it has won the Pulitzer Prize in drama, received a record-breaking 16 Tony nominations, winning 11, and last fall apparently broke the Broadway record in advance sales.

But more than just being the hottest thing in American culture, Hamilton is an attempt to rewrite American history. Drawing from Ron Chernow‚Äôs biography of Alexander Hamilton and working in rap, hip-hop and show tunes, Miranda has breathed new life into the story of one of the Founding Fathers, reframing the life of the first Treasury secretary as the story of a poor Caribbean immigrant from a broken home who succeeded thanks to relentless ambition. Hamilton no doubt takes liberties: Some critics say it overly reveres Hamilton, not to mention that its cast is mostly black and Latino; Miranda, whose parents are Puerto Rican, played the part of Hamilton until this summer. But these modern touches are meant to draw a line from the messiness of early-American politics to today‚Äôs. ‚ÄúI think the notion of our founders being these perfect men who got these stone tablets from the sky that became our Constitution and Bill of Rights is bullshit,‚Äù Miranda told Rolling Stone.

It‚Äôs sure been ages since a #Broadway play had such resonance in politics; Miranda even successfully urged Treasury Secretary Jack Lew to keep the newly hip Hamilton on the front of the soon-to-be-redesigned $10 bill. And it‚Äôs no surprise that Miranda has become a supercelebrity in a year when anti-immigrant rhetoric has spiked. In fact, his critique of Donald Trump‚Äôs plan to build a wall has clear historical, even Hamiltonian resonances: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs such a malignant form of a very common American electoral disease,‚Äù Miranda has said, ‚Äúwhich is, ‚ÄòPoint at the newest people here and say they‚Äôre the reason you‚Äôre broke.‚Äô That‚Äôs as old as time itself.‚Äù Click on the link in bio for the full POLITICO 50 list. üì∑: Hilary Swift/The New York Times/Redux

From POLITICO‚Äôs Katie Glueck: BEL AIR, Calif. ‚Äî Past a pair of Rolls-Royces parked in the driveway and a bodyguard who answers the door, the first thing you encounter upon entering Toni Holt Kramer‚Äôs house is a picture of Donald Trump.

This Hollywood reporter turned bicoastal socialite is the founder of ‚ÄúTrumpettes USA,‚Äù a group of mostly high-society female friends and admirers of the GOP nominee ‚Äî including Gennifer Flowers, of Bill Clinton sex scandal notoriety ‚Äî dedicated to making Trump America‚Äôs next president.

Kramer gathered members of her club here, at her palatial home in the Los Angeles area, while their candidate worked a barn full of farmers in Iowa last Saturday. They discussed opportunities for pro-Trump events and venues for fundraisers, but mostly these ladies who lunch spent six hours together talking up the man several of them consider a longtime friend. And in the process, they provided a gilded window into the ultra-elite social circle Trump ran in for decades, before he descended a few steps on America‚Äôs glamour ladder to conquer the Republican Party.

The world of Trump and the Trumpettes is unsubtly wealthy, full of knuckle-sized bejeweled rings and multiple vacation homes. Its residents are ideologically flexible: Like Trump, they have donated extensively to both parties and claim friendships with power players across the political spectrum. (Kramer says she has been both a friend and donor to Hillary Clinton.) And like Trump, the Trumpettes and their male counterparts, ‚Äúthe Trumpsters,‚Äù are politically incorrect ‚Äî often much more so than the proudly irreverent nominee himself.

According to a POLITICO investigation, the Obama administration and #Congress have all but squandered an opportunity to give the anemic Food and Drug Administration, which is responsible for the safety of 80 percent of the nation‚Äôs #food supply, a level of oversight the public long assumed it already had.

On paper, the law that Congress passed in late 2010 ‚Äî known as the Food Safety Modernization Act ‚Äî was bigger than anything since #TheodoreRoosevelt cleaned up the meatpacking industry. The law mandated more inspections and much tougher anti-contamination standards for everything from peaches to imported pesto sauce, and it placed more emphasis on preventing outbreaks than on chasing them down after people become sick.

But almost five years later, not one of the sweeping new rules has been implemented and funding is more than $276 million behind where it needs to be. A law that could have been legacy-defining for President @BarackObama instead represents a startling example of a broad and bipartisan policy initiative stymied by #politics and the neglect of some of its strongest proponents.

Link to full Broken By Design investigation in bio. | Graphic: 5W Infographics

The #SouthCarolina state Senate voted overwhelmingly Monday to remove the Confederate battle flag from state house grounds. But the debate over Confederate images is far from over. The battle flag is etched in stone on monuments to Confederate leaders throughout the South, and some lawmakers and civic leaders are calling for their removal from public grounds. Virginia Gov. #terrymcauliffe ‚Äì who has said he will recall the state's battle flag license plates ‚Äì has defended the continued public display of statues. "These are all parts of our heritage," McAuliffe said during an interview with MSNBC's Andrea Mitchell. As the debate continues, POLITICO takes a look at some of the monuments in #Virginia that supporters say represent Southern heritage and critics deem a symbol of hate. Link in bio. Shown is a monument to Robert E. Lee along Monument Avenue in #Richmond, Virginia. Standing at 60 feet, the monument to Lee was the first, and remains the largest, monument along the city's historic avenue. | Photo: M. #TBT: President John F. Kennedy addresses the nation on civil rights on June 11, 1963. Alabama Gov. George Wallace had refused a federal court order that two black students, Vivian Malone and James Hood, be admitted to the University of #Alabama at Tuscaloosa. The events surrounding this denial of the court order culminated in the delivery of the speech by Kennedy. Wallace finally capitulated after the National Guard was federalized. From #JFK's address: "We preach freedom around the world, and we mean it, and we cherish our freedom here at home; but are we to say to the world, and, much more importantly, for each other, that this is a land of the free except for the Negroes; that we have no second-class citizens except Negroes; that we have no class or caste system, no ghettos, no master race, except with respect to Negroes?" | Photo: Associated Press #history #presidents #photos #ovaloffice #whitehouse #civilrights

#WhatWorks: The Fiesta District, which previously housed an unfrequented Bed Bath & Beyond, Petco and Circuit City, is currently home to a major revitalization project. Phoenix Rising Investments recently acquired a plaza that had been vacant for years and plans to turn it into over 100,000 square feet of office space. Photo: @markpetersonpixs

#WhatWorks: Albert Wick, an octogenarian snowbird from Ohio, has spent 13 years in Mesa. Because of balmy temperatures that hover above 60 degrees even in January, strong religious communities‚ÄîMesa is mostly Catholic, Mormon and Evangelical‚Äîand retirement communities and assisted living centers all reserved for the elderly, Mesa has become a hot destination for retirees. The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that 15.8 percent of Mesa‚Äôs population is over the age of 65, compared with 13.7 of the country at large. Photo:
@markpetersonpixs

#WhatWorks: James Sullivan has worked at Transitional Living Communities, a recovery center for homeless substance abusers, for about a year. He is 65 years old. Photo: 
@markpetersonpixs

#WhatWorks: Despite the brutal toll the 2008 financial crisis took on Mesa, the city is continuing to lure in development through pro-growth conservative governance.
